reviews.review_title: My brief review of the film
reviews.content: A pleasant enough to watch collection of amusing anecdotes, as told from a child's perspective, with certain events and the adult characters appropriately exaggerated - however they come off as too over-the-top and silly for their purpose. The main problem with the film though is the overly zealous narration. Whenever the narrator talks he sounds ridiculous - nothing like an old man reflecting on his boyhood. The film also has noticeable gaps between the entertaining bits. It captures childhood spirit well, thanks in part to a reasonably good lead performance, but arguably not so much Christmas spirit. Not a bad film overall, but nothing really special. There are funnier and more touching Christmas films around.

reviews.review_title: Ralphie to the rescue, oh oh....
reviews.content: So goes the lyrics to a big production number in the stage musical version of this Christmas classic, transferred so successfully that it became the first limited Christmas Broadway show to get a Tony Nomination for Best Musical. Re-visiting that show again for its Madison Square Garden engagement, I reflected on the movie which has become a Christmas perennial, showed repeatedly on cable stations every December, sometimes as long as 24 hours without going to another program! Growing up in a small town in New York in the mid 1970's where Christmas was celebrated in the old fashioned sense, I could relate to every aspect of this film which took place some 20 years before.Pretty much everyone can relate to that one present they desperately wished for when they were a child, even if it wasn't a red-ryder beebee gun. "You'll shoot your eye out, kid!", everybody tells him, and in the musical, there's even a huge production number where his fourth grade teacher Miss Shields sings and dances in red sequins after giving him the notorious C+. Miss Shields (Tedde Moore) doesn't sing and dance here, but she's still part of Robby's fantasies. Greeting the teacher with monster teeth attached to their own, the kids turn them in to which she adds these choppers to a collection of other trinkets she's taken away from children not paying attention to their lessons over the years. The story focuses on Ralphie's family, which includes Darren McGavin as the irritable father, Melinda Dillon as the sweet and understanding mother, and Ian Petrella as the adolescent Randy who is sort of mistreated comically as he eats mashed potatoes like a pig and is over-wrapped in winter clothes which make it impossible for him to keep his arms down. Ralphie is played by the adorable Peter Billingsley who went onto produce the stage musical version, and he truly is the dream version of the every day kid. Disciplined and polite (even if he does utter a curse word in one very funny scene), he is still a 9 year old in every sense of the word, prankish and funny, and cutely geeky. Jean Shepherd (the adult Ralphie) provides the witty narration, giving the viewer an inside look into what life was like in the mid west when tradition was everything.This film has so many wonderful moments, and even if I don't watch it every year (seeing the musical twice over the past two holiday seasons did it justice for me), I still look back on it fondly. Who hasn't experienced a nightmare visit to Santa in the local department store right before the holidays where nasty assistants and a possible inebriated fat man in a Santa suit hasn't hurried them along as the night rolls to an end? Who hasn't been humiliated by an obnoxious present by a well-meaning relative who thinks that a 9-year old would look cute in a pink bunny suit? Who hasn't wondered what it would be like to stick their tongue on something frozen? (I know that a certain member of my family actually did, and with much regret too...)Also memorable is the prize which McGavin receives from one of the many contests he's entered (nothing like a good old leg o' lamp...) and his constant fighting with the furnace, plus Dillon's reaction to the "Chinese Turkey" they receive when the downtrodden neighbor's dogs steal their own. Lots of subtle innuendos too about kids of this day, particularly one goggle-clad little boy in line to see Santa who declares to Ralphie, "I like "The Wizard of Oz". I like the tin man!" as Ralphie tells the woman in the wicked witch costume to beat it. While this film had a rather small theatrical release and appears to have been a sleeper of the time, it has certainly erupted into cult status, even providing an obscure sequel, "It Runs in the Family", once re-titled "A Summer Story" for VHS release. (That film is memorable for me for a sequence in which Mary Steenburgen as the mother tired of receiving a gravy boat at a local movie theater, started a riot by tossing her umpteenth one at the nervous host of the dish giveaway.) It is in that film too where the secret of the Kettle like next door neighbors is revealed.

The film, of a boy's Christmas when he was nine and the year was in or about 1940, is a worthwhile view. The story of Ralphie and his boyish dream, specifically telling everyone who wanted to, or didn't, that his greatest Christmas wish was to get a Red Ryder Carbine BB Gun was reminiscent of what a lot of people went through at about the same age. Ralphie's peripheral dealings in school are also familiar to a lot of those who experienced similar things in their youth. Various events like coping with bullies are told in Jean Shepherd's easygoing style, and he was a natural raconteur.Spoilers Follow: There are a few things in the film that create a jarring note for those familiar with the times. One of the other things Ralphie wanted intensely was a decoder pin for the Little Orphan Annie radio show. He finally finds an Ovaltine tin, and sends for one. After an interminable wait, one arrives in the mail, and he waits to receive the first message. He excitedly deciphers it, and the message is, "Be sure to drink your Ovaltine." A commercial, he thinks disgustedly. But there's a problem: the story's bogus. The film took care to be "authentic," using a large number of antique autos on its street scenes, and providing Ralphie with a genuine Radio Orphan Annie Secret Society 1940 Speedomatic Decoder Pin. It was a good choice, since the number and letter scales on the pin were at its peripheral edges, making Ralphie's fumbling to decipher the message more frantic. However, the actual messages were invariably hints about the forthcoming episode, never commercials. I've been told that Jean Shepherd once remarked that he wouldn't let facts stand in the way of a good story.Likewise, the Red Ryder Carbine. It was supposed to have a compass in its stock, and something that could tell time. I got a Red Ryder Carbine BB gun some seven years after the show was supposed to have taken place, and good gun as it was, it didn't have or need the extra items.But if you bleep through those things, it's an excellent piece of entertainment, well worth watching, particularly in the Christmas season.

Christmas is when kids want it all. Their favorite toy, their favorite video, no socks. Christmas morning is the most eagerly anticipated 2 hour period of the year for many, and the movie A Christmas Story shows us why. The minute the last speck of the Thanksgiving turkey leaves your plate until you wake up Christmas morning, the season of giving, but more importantly for kids (and some adults) getting, is in full swing. Anything is possible, Santa has a sleigh full of presents, just for Ralphie (Peter Billingsly) is just waiting for Dec. 24. All Peter wants is a Red Rider BB Gun, the one your mother, and every other mother in the world, tells you that you'll shoot your eye out with. Ralphie uses the days leading up to the classic 1950s American Christmas trying to find a way to get his BB Gun. He writes a theme for his school teacher, he tries to convince his parents that there were grizzly bears at his Indiana town's candy store, he even asks the big guy Santa for a gun. All requests were pushed aside with the now famous phrase "You'll shoot your eye out!" The scene involving Santa (Jeff Gillin) is especially funny, a scene right out of Bad Santa which came out 20 years later. Originally thought of as a failed adaptation of Jean Shepherd's book "In God We Trust, All Others Pay Cash" about his childhood (Shepherd narrates the movie and has a cameo appearance as an irate father, scolding Raphie and his brother Randy for cutting in line to see Santa) by director Bob Clark (infamous for the Porky's movies), A Christmas Story caught on in the mid-1990s as a holiday tradition, one cable network even devotes 24 hours Christmas Day showing the movie over and over and over and over again. The reason I think the movie has become a holiday favorite is that parents can watch this movie about a kid and his Christmas dreams and enjoy the look back at their childhood. We all knew fathers like Ralphie's (Darren McGavin) who would be a happy man if the Bears won and the furnace didn't falter everyday. We all knew mothers like Ralphie's (Melinda Dillon) who is stern with her kids, but will stick up for them when they needed it. I don't know if we all knew siblings like Ralphie's brother, Randy (Ian Petrella), but I certainly did. We still fight the same way Ralphie and Randy did to this day. Christmas is all about family, whether we like it or not.

reviews.review_title: Christmas Story still A BIG HIT 30 years later!
reviews.content: I never got to see "The Christmas Story" in a Movie theater. It was rushed in and out of theaters at Thanksgiving time in 83;so most people/fans have only seen it on TV. After viewing this movie only once, it instantly became my favorite Christmas Film moving ahead of "IT'S A WONDERFUL LIFE" which I had watched for decades.Even though I grew up in the 50's I could easily identify with Ralphie.Parents/Santa were still giving BB Guns at Chrismas to young boys. I was 7 years old(can you imagine giving a BB GUN to a 7 yr old today)and actually don't remember even asking for a BB GUN but was more than thrilled when I discovered it under our Christmas Tree.Billingsley(Ralphie) did such a superb acting performance in this film,it still amazes me. His Facial Expressions without even saying a word were the highlight throughout the movie. The innocent look he tried to portray when he and Schwartz convinced FLICK to put his tongue on the Flagpole after a Triple dog dare yah! When Ms Shields can't get Flick to tattle on who was responsible for his dilemma.She knew it had to be Ralphie and Schwartz but how are you going to prove it if Flick won't spill the beans.Just a wonderfully entertaining Movie that doesn't really get boring anywhere in the Film. Great performances by the supporting cast also. When you watch a Film like this going on 30 years you can't really see anyone else playing the parts other than the Original Actors. I recently got a glimpse of "CHRISTMAS STORY 2" and just couldn't get into it with Daniel Stern playing the Old Man or any of the other non original cast members. Another instance of Leaving Well Enough alone.Anyone that watches this Film and can't come away with some kind of a good feeling or happy memory from their life probably won't like or care for anything worthwhile during their life.Sadly Darren McGavin and Bob Clark are no longer with us;but they both know what this film meant to millions of people...Excellent 5 Star Film in my book...s.m.

The beautiful little film is a treasure, and an accurate portrayl of kiddom and Life in General in the 1930s and '40s.  Thank goodness for Bob Clark, Darrin McGavin, Ms. Dillon, and Peter Billingsley, all of whom had the spark of genius in the making of the movie.  It wouldn't be Christmas without it!

reviews.review_title: One of the best Christmas movies ever
reviews.content: A Christmas Story is a classic in my book even though it's made in 1983. I've watched it almost every Christmas season and laughed every time at the HO HO HOs and the sticking of the tongue to the flag pole. That is what makes it a classic and great movie.A Christmas Story tells the story of Ralphie Parker and one Christmas season. All he wants is one Red Ryder BB gun for Christmas. One great aspect of the movie is that we relate to it. We have always wanted that one toy or something for Christmas(or Hanukkah). We didn't know if we were going to get it until that morning especially for Ralphie. But getting that gun isn't the only thing this movie is about. It's about being a kid and the daily trials that kids go through. Bullies, dares, teachers, fake radio clubs that are only advertisements. There's another way we can relate to this movie. Most of us have had bullies, dares, teachers you've tried to impress, and so on. The list goes on and on(I'm still thinking of some right now). Of course Palphie will go long distances to get that BB gun pulling every trick in the book. Along the way we meet an array of characters and we are introduced to many stories that again, we can relate to. The characters are all ones that you might have had in your life. The only one missing is the crush of Ralphie. We have the mans man dad, the forgiving yet unforgiving mom and the weird little brother that you make fun of. Then you have Ralphie's best friends which played a small role length wise but still are memorable. The narration by Jean Sheppard is one of the strong parts of the movie. The way he describes some of the situations can produce some laughs if you listen closely to it. Now to my favorite part of the movie. Christmas morning. If it's December and i'm not in the Christmas mood, this movie will but me right in it after seeing this scene. It has to be the perfect depiction of Christmas morning i've seen. Nothing else comes close to the elation and chaos of this rare moment, and of course the moment when he gets the BB gun. It puts a smile to my face every time. Memories pour into your head of Christmas' past. Of good presents and the bad ones, and just being together with your family being happy. What a great moment.In conclusion, this is a must see Christmas classic that you will see every year and will always relate to it 10/10

This is a highly regarded Christmas movie that gets almost universal praise. In my day-to-day life, I've never heard a single person speak ill of the film. And I love Christmas movies. So, I bit the bullet and bought a copy of the film to watch this Christmas season. I wasn't really sure what to expect, so I went in with an open mind and open heart, expecting a heartwarming Christmas tale like some of the other great Warner Bros. Christmas films (Jack Frost, To Grandmother's House We Go, Grandma Got Run Over By a Reindeer... the stuff normal people despised but that I can find some enjoyment in, in one way or another).
Wow, what played out on screen did not give me a pleasant experience, and I would be lying if I said otherwise.
Firstly, Ralphie is extremely annoying. Peter Bilingsley was likely giving it the best he could given the quality of the script he was working with, but man is that character a real piece of work. Cheapened even further with the narration of an adult Ralphie throughout the film externalizing the character's thoughts at key moments of the film, the character isn't likeable. Sure, he fit the Hollywood mould for kid actors in the looks department at the time (he was a pretty face to plaster on the movie poster), but that's really all the character has going for himself. And to build the entire premise of the film around the idea that this kid wants a gun for Christmas makes no sense. It's not funny, it's not clever and it's certainly not entertaining. It's macabre and, as someone who enjoys an extremely dark sense of humour, it was still a major miss.
The movie is dull from beginning to end. At just over 90 minutes, it felt like it dragged on far too long, which is not a good look for a standard-length film. This is the kind of thing you can probably enjoy with the rose-tinted glasses of nostalgia, but without that you're left with a film that everybody loses their minds over every Christmas that just doesn't hold up.
The only thing I can figure is that there's something in this film - some redeemable factor that changes everything - that went completely over my head, which isn't likely because this film panders directly to children of a lesser intelligence, spoon-feeding them every step along the way instead of letting the story develop naturally and allowing the viewer to draw their own conclusions. As a general film, it was bland and boring. As a Christmas film it was a holiday disaster (a "No-Ho-Ho," as some film reviewers may refer to it). As a Warner Bros. holiday release... well, the commercials on the VHS before the actual movie were more enjoyable than the film. The excuse, however, can be made that it's an MGM release that Warner Bros. acquired, so it's not technically a Warner Bros. film.
I hope they didn't pay too much for it. Thank god, neither did I.
Great nostalgia! I lived much of it. Born in 1938 and raised in Indiana, the film seemed autobiographical. Well done!

the consummate christmas movie. the camera work is deceptively good, the style is lively, independent and fits perfectly with the feel/tone of the film, and the narrative command is perfect. from beginning to end this movie breathes like few films, especially of this kind, do. every performance is flawless and it appeals to people of all ages. the end both confirms the reality of the world (one that grownups know all too well) and fits with one that kids, too, can appreciate - the broken toy on christmas day feeling. a fantastic film deserving of no less than an A+. this one has withstood the test of time.

reviews.review_title: One Of The Best Holiday Movies
reviews.content: For me, it's not Christmas unless I've seen Albert Finney as Scrooge, Jimmy Sterwart have a paranormal event and seen Ralphie Parker blow his eye out. "A Christmas Story" is the best holiday movie to watch to avoid not aving the spirit shoved down my throat. It reminds me of all the hassling and fighting in a normal family and a few more. The leg in the window, tongue to the pole, the gifts you don't want, the school reports and the consumerism that doesn't go away till after Valentine's Day. Ralphie is essentially the every kid with all the problems. Darren McGavin is the father I'd want over Mr. Brady or even Mr. Cleaver. He's more fun, but I gotta lament for him as his beloved turkey vanishes. He should have shot those neighbor dogs with his son's Official Red Ryder Rifle ! Ralphie could then use it on those dim-witted bullies (why Ralphie and his cronies don't just ignore them is beyond me ). This is one of the best !

reviews.review_title: The most initially underrated film of all time
reviews.content: How well I remember attending this movie on the first day of its initial release, loving it, and being shocked that critics savaged it. Yes, not just disliked, but hated this movie. Not every critic, mind you--there is Roger Ebert, after all--but just take a look at The New York Times. That's one of the more positive original reviews (and it's an outright pan itself). My suspicion is that critics just couldn't get their heads around the fact that Bob Clark, director of the loathed "Porky's," could create a work as wonderful as this one. Clark, in fact, has two masterpieces to his credit, this movie and "Black Christmas," the scariest slasher movie of them all. Both have "Christmas" in the title, and both represent the top of their genres--nostalgia in "Story" and horror in "Black." Clark had talent--and here is evidence as clear as a Christmas bell.Oh, and let's not forget the great Jean Shepherd, Darren McGavin, Melida Dillon, and Peter Billingsley. What a great writer/narrator/cast!

There are very few films which I would give 10 to and this is one of them. The reason is that I can identify almost 100% with Ralph Parker, the main character in "A Christmas Story". The story revolves around 9 year old Ralph Parker and his quest to get a "Genuine Red Rider 200 shot carbine action air rifle" for Christmas. At every turn he is told "you'll shoot your eye out, kid" and along the way Ralph lives through many of the Christmas and childhood adventures and mishaps that I remember: There is the scheming to get the present you want, there is the father who swears a blue streak trying to fix a furnace that doesn't want to be fixed, there is the neighborhood bully who terrorizes Ralph and his friends, there is the doting mother always worried about you putting your eye out, there is the washing your mouth out with soap after saying a 'bad' word ( the daydream Ralph has about being blinded after the incident by 'soap poisoning' is a laugh riot ), there is the rich daydream world kids often visit while envisioning their deepest wishes, there is the, often, terrorizing visit to Santa Claus, and a ton of other identifiable childhood conditions. Whenever I watch this movie ( too many times to count ), I'm 8 years old again. There are very few movies that can pull you in like that, which is what makes it so great. The movie is perfectly cast, which is also one of the reasons you recognize all the characters in the movie.Most people seem to really like this movie, but there are a few who don't. The funny thing is they seem to object to the very things ( like children repeating the swears they hear their father using ) that make this movie so special. It's honest, that's what they don't like. They would rather watch and have their children watch the "Peter Pan"s and "Cinderella"s which sugarcoat everything and have very little to do with real childhood.If you haven't seen this movie and appreciate life like characters and situations, this movie is a have-to-see that'll also have you busting a gut laughing and get you right into the holiday spirit.

reviews.review_title: when will this be released in the UK on DVD?
reviews.content: I was seven when I first saw this and despite its US setting could totally relate and the muffled up brother still brings a smile to my face today. So pleased to see I'm not the only one who gets a kick out of little boys with guns and electric sex in the window. I don't know whether it wasn't marketed properly or whether the distributors felt the UK wouldn't get the joke but it is like getting hold of hen's teeth over here. Sort it out someone. It has humour in it to suit just about anyone of any age and although, it has little to do with religion, says more about Christmas as I know it than almost anything else. Can not be missed, send any spare copies in charity parcels to the UK, then we just need the right players.

All I could think of is "It's a TERRIBLE film." Christmas Story seems to be a mockery of everything that Christmas should stand for. The film is depressing and lewd. Violence, tis' the season to be shooting, is a theme of the film. It is truly the worst Christmas movie ever. If you want your children to see a more uplifting Christmas film - I would suggest Bad Santa. Or if you don't celebrate Christmas, perhaps Schindler's List. The acting is terrible and the child star is a true Christmas dwarf. Maybe Santa needs a new 'helper' - which is probably what the actor is up to today. :(

Story of one youngster's Christmas in Depression-era Indiana steel town. Author was the irrepressible master of nostalgia, Jean Shepherd, who used to ramble on WOR radio for hours about Flick, Schwartz and the rest of his childhood.  Hasn't hurt it's popularity that this movie is TNT's annual Christmas marathon.  Look for Shep himself briefly in department store, telling Ralph where the line really ends.  10/10

I've been watching "A Christmas Story" every year for as long as I can remember. It's a true Christmas classic, one of the funniest and most memorable film of all-time.Anyone who ever wanted a certain object for Christmas can identify with little Ralphie Parker (Peter Billingsly), who wants nothing more than a Red Ryder BB-Gun. And what child has never schemed to get what they really wanted? But poor Ralphie is faced with the same response- 'You'll Shoot Your Eye Out!'. Supporting characters- Ralph's little brother Randy, two best friends, his teacher at school, and his mom and dad all add hilarious elements of comedy. One note I would like to make- Someone else on this board noted that this movie was an example of the moral decline in America, and that the claim that this movie was better than "It's a Wonderful Life" or "Miracle on 34th Street" was pretty much assinine. I personally disgree, and I believe that "A Christmas Story" is an equally warm and sweet movie. Some of us have a sense of humor, that's all.

reviews.review_title: Overrated and problematic, but with some merits
reviews.content: This movie is often presented as one of the best Christmas films, but it is very overrated. There is the intention of representing the spirit of childhood, and indeed it succeeds in doing it for that particular country USA white middle class children, but it does it in a significantly problematic way. It is more apologetic than critical to a violent traditional society, to USA "freemen" ideology despite the repeating warnings "you'll shoot your eye out", which seem more a gag on an unimportant issue (whar the end of the story reaffirms). The simple fact of relating Christmas celebration to rifles and killing is bizarre, and could not have happened in any other country but the United States (perhaps also in Canada...). Well, that does not mean that the film has no quality: indeed, there is a lot of good dark humor, with interesting cartoon-like overacting scenes representing the boy's imagination, and the troubled but indulgent relationship between his parents is very well and ironically addressed. However, that narration with mannerisms is boring. It is also problematic that all characters are white; all but four Chinese employees in an ethnic restaurant, who appear just to be object of jokes (as a matter of fact, Chinese people had been mentioned twice before, being related once to starving and in the second time with torture). To resume, it is not a bad movie, but it is very average, quite overrated, and problematic for multiple reasons.

Might Contain SpoilersYet another overhyped piece of junk on the IMDB top 250. I can't understand why this film is so loved, every Christmas eve night @ the party, my cousins insist upon watching it. It stars a kid who looks like the one from Jerry McGwire who wants a gun for Christmas. He basicaly goes through a lot of odd events to get it. This film is for kids who think that if they whine and complain enough, they'll get whatever they want for Christmas. I suggest National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation if you want a good enough Christmas Comedy for repeat viewing during the Hollidays.

reviews.review_title: A Charming Surprise for the Christmas Season
reviews.content: Every now and then, I find myself watching a film that is considered a classic, yet my parents never exposed me to it. "A Christmas Story" was one of those very movies. I'm nineteen at this moment, and have just now seen it for the first time in my life. Even my mother had never seen the movie before, and I could not resist making her sit down yesterday and watching it for her very first time, as well. You see, the film is charming in ways that I cannot begin to express. It is simply a film that you must view at least once in your life. Many emotions came to mind with all three viewings I've given "A Christmas Story": joy, hope, more joy, weariness, more joy, sadness, and then a LOT of joy to collect the ending moments. With all of that said, I'll begin my actual review.When young Ralphie spots a Red Ryder BB gun in the toy store window one day, he begins to find ways to drop many, many hints to his parents. His little ways of asking them and attempting to convince them to get him one this Christmas are typically futile, because all everyone seems to say in reply is: "No, you'll shoot your eye out." However, Ralphie just won't give up on this excellent craft by the human hand--this wood-and-metal, BB-firing masterpiece! Peter Billingsly, when advertised on the commercials for the day-long re-runs surrounding the approach of Christmas day, seemed annoying. I avoided the film many times, even when the opportunity arose to see it. To my surprise, he is mostly good, but has his irritating moments. He brought the character of Ralphie to life, in my opinion. Ralphie becomes so relatable to my memories of me as a very young child. Like I mentioned numerous times above: joy constantly lit my heart during this movie. The mother, father, and younger brother actors were all fantastic, as well! Overall, the supporting cast were just as good as the lead.When it comes to the writing, I'll be honest that some of the jokes just aren't that funny, in my opinion. For example: the scenes Ralphie conjures about the things he would do with his Red Ryder BB gun are so silly that I get a little peeved by how long they tend to draw out. They are sluggish, in a way. However, these small complaints can only knock a single star off from a perfect 10 in my rating, because everything else about the film is absolutely brilliant! The events are what unravel this movie in such a genuine way that you can't help but smile to yourself. The film itself is essentially perceived through the eyes of a child, so I understand why some not-very-funny things are included with the film. Much to my surprise, the film is not just for kids; it has quite a bit to offer parents regarding jokes and situations.I also want to mention that there is a specific point with Ralphie after a long school day that literally broke my heart. It has a small bit of comedy in this scene, but the overwhelming tone of how upset Ralphie had gotten made me tear-up.Like I said before: the film is a charm.My God, what a fantastic film.If you get a chance to see this hilarious little treat, please don't pass it up like I did! You'll regret it! My rating for "A Christmas Story" is a nine-out-of-ten stars.God bless, and Merry Christmas!

What can i say about this movie? It's a classic for this yuletide holiday, and i enjoy watching it every time. The story of Ralphie's desire for a Red Rider BB gun for christmas is funny, and heartwarming at the same time, and shouldn't be missed on t.v. every christmas. After all, what movie can you hear the phrase: "you'll shoot your eye out", or see a "major reward" like the old man's leg lamp?A great christmas movie for all.

This has become a yearly viewing treat for me and my son. The source of the movie's charm is the wonderful writing of Jean Shepherd, on whose colorfully nostalgic short stories of growing up in 1950's midwest U.S. this film is based. The fact that this low-budget sleeper has become such a well-loved holiday movie by so many is a tribute to Shepherd. My one reservation is that I think Darren McGavin is a bit miscast as the father; they could have used someone a tad more 'salt-of-the-earth-ish'. Also, we could do without Randy's 'piggy' scene.  Having said that, there are so many wonderful moments here: the 'double-dog-dare-ya' scene ("Does anyone know where Flick is?"), the tire-fixing scene, the famous lamp, "you'll shoot your eye out", and on and on. This wonderful movie is good clean fun with a lot of nostalgic warmth.

A classic film I grew up watching yearly for many years. I was born in the early 1970s and my Christmas' were similar to Ralphie Parker. I'm a female but I've shot BB guns, read comics, ordered things out of comics, pulling pranks, making and taking dares, sitting on Santa's lap, hinted and begged my parents for much desired Christmas gifts, beat up school bullies... I could be Ralphie's sister!Who doesn't like when Ralphie wailed on Scut Farkus? He got what he deserved! Funny scene!Bar of soap in the mouth? I'm so happy my parents never went that far when a dirty word passed my lips.Reminder: NEVER put your tongue to metal during the winter!I could highlight more of the film but you should watch it for yourself if you've never seen it - it's pretty good.9/10.

reviews.review_title: A Christmas movie I thought I'd imagined.
reviews.content:
I must have seen this movie in the late 80s as a kid (born in 82). I had vivid memories of Santa kicking ralphitralphiehe slide and the other kid getting his tongue stuck to the pole. And that was it.
It wasn't until a few days ago, fast forward to December 2020 and I saw an Instagram post about this movie and realised this was the movie that was stuck in the back of my head for over 30 years.I rented a digital copy and sat down and watched it that night.This movie stirs up so much nostalgia, even for me born decades after this movie was set. Though I think growing up in the early 80s is closer to the 40s or 50s than today possibly is lile for children.
My family had 1 tv, a stay at home mum, were fairly poor, walked to school, I had a younger brother and i definitely dreamed of getting one specific toy each Christmas. The super soaker 50 springs to mind one particular year.I think the Christmas message does come through in this film and its clear to me why this movie holds such a strong place to so many people especially the generationgenerations before mine. But I hope newer generations find something in this simple little story about growing up in hard times and figuring out the world and the people you look up to who you think have the world figured out. But even they really don't.I will add this to my list of end of year movies forever now and I'm so happy I rediscovered it after all these years.It's not a classic Christmas story like a christmas carol or its a wonderful life which are magical in their own rights. But a christmas movie paints a picture of a real Christmas lead up so many of us lived. Remembering back to being that age and having that expectation and wonderment for Christmas day. In its own way this movie is very touching and a nice coming of age story for ralphie.I'm so happy to hear that a channel in America plays this for 24 hours straight.

I love this movie. It is so funny. The whole story is the true to life experience of Jean Shepard. Jean Shepard is an excellent writer and short story. He use to have this program on PBS that was so great. He could really weave his words. I thought there was great depth to all the characters that are in this movie. I love the mother, father, both boys, the teacher . Each character was excellent. This is a joy of a film. It is not sugary, which is propably why it appeals to me. A true Classic.

reviews.review_title: Why oh why is this considered a classic?
reviews.content: Unlike the majority of people on the planet, I didn't find this movie very amusing at all.  I thought it was rather aimless and not all that funny and clever.  It even dragged in parts.  "The Wonder Years" borrowed heavily from the format here.  It rides the wave of the nostalgia-based period piece and falls into many conventions.  The acting wasn't all that horrible, it was actually the narration that got on my nerves most of all.  Beyond that, it was just plain boring!  Not one of my Christmas favorites by a long shot, I still don't understand why it is enjoying 24-hour marathons on TNT.

I cannot add more to the superlatives already posted here for A CHRISTMAS STORY. The film captures perfectly the ambiance of life in the simpler era that existed just prior to American involvement in World War Two. The exact year of the story is never stated, but I believe that it must have been set in either 1939 or 1940. There are numerous depictions of characters from THE WIZARD OF OZ and SNOW WHITE during the parade and department store sequences, and both these films had just been released during that time frame.I was fortunate to have grown up during the 1950s, and to have experienced the tail end of this era during my childhood. With each viewing of A CHRISTMAS STORY, all the warm memories of that time come rushing back. I feel sorry for those detractors who can find no value here, and cannot identify with the simpler, more cohesive lifestyle that existed long before the era of television and video games. How sad and empty your lives must be.

I'm so happy for the late Bob Clark who got to see his Masterpiece become an annual TV Christmas classic. Kudos also to the great humorist Jean Shepherd for choosing and trusting in Bob to put his gem of a Christmas story on film. Where does one begin? Well, you need a great, engrossing story to make a classic film and Jean Sherpherd's "In God we trust..." is perfection. His childhood recollections are "spot on"! It was a risk to choose Bob Clark, whose credits included "Black Christmas" and "Porky's" and who'd a thunk he'd deliver in spades! Next, and extremely important, is a good cast. Here's where the film excels. The casting is superb, from the leads to the smaller roles. Peter Billingsley is a perfect 'Ralphie' (who has been portrayed by Matt Dillon, Jerry O'Connell and Kieran Culkin). Darren McGavin is excellent as 'the Old Man' as is Melinda Dillon as 'Mom'. Both are perfect parents, strict yet loving and in the end supportive. McGavin is terrific as a short-tempered furnace hating dad. Dillon adds moments of humor, wonder and warmth. Ian Petrella steals ever scene he's in as whiny, frustrated younger brother Randy. Jean Shepherd has a small cameo role as a grumpy man waiting in the line for visiting Santa Claus. Ralphie's buddies, Flick (Scott Schwartz), and Schwartz (R.D. Robb) and neighborhood bully, Scut Farkas (Zack Ward) are also wonderful in their roles. The movie is charmingly nostalgic and anyone who celebrated Christmas as a kid should be able to relate to this film. The entire film is seen from a kid's perspective. Shepherd and Clark do such a fantastic job of capturing the trials and tribulations of pre-teen kids that it's just remarkable. Though set in the early 1940s, it so closely mirrors my childhood in the 1950s and most likely many of the following generations of kids. Watching this film in December guarantees the viewer a very Merry Christmas!

reviews.review_title: Seriously. What is the hype with this crap?
reviews.content: I saw this movie since it was mentioned a lot by everyone as a "classic", funny and heartwarming story about Christmas. So, naturally, I decide to check it out because I try to be open about seeing a movie that I haven't seen before. Man, I should have listened to myself after the first ten minutes of the movie.To give some context, I worked at a day camp for little kids. Some were great, some were not. And those who were not good kids were brats. Huge brats. And whenever I saw Ralphie on screen, I wanted to slap him so hard. Not to mention his parents who are so incoherently bad.Are we supposed to root for Ralphie this whole movie? All he wants is a Red Ryder BB gun and thinks Christmas will be ruined if he doesn't get it. Oh well, at least have a scene where he throws a big tantrum and I'd consider reviewing this movie even better, but no. He gets the gun, shoots his cheek, breaks his glasses and tells a lie. AND HIS MOTHER BELIEVES HIM! AND HE GETS AWAY WITH IT IN THE END! What happened to telling the truth and learning lessons like so many Christmas movies have done? This movie threw that away and it's hard to sympathize with a kid who lies and acts bratty an entire film.The movie was disappointing and wouldn't recommend it to my worst enemy. The parents are so dumb, Ralphie is a brat who gets away with everything and the story (yes, it's presented in vignettes, which works in some movies, not this one) is so disjointed, and even the comedy attempts are ridiculously lame. I like Darren McGavin in his other roles but this one makes him so hateable that I feel bad he got this role. I'm sorry but watch other Christmas movies that have a lesson or some nice story behind it and not one about a brat.

Poor Ralphie. On top of involvement in the struggle to win a perfect Christmas present, he is also besieged by bullies, an overly gruff father, and the occasional poor grade. But what a typical childhood it is. After using the opening minutes to deceive us into thinking this is just another comedy, the film's creators give us a story that strongly resembles many of our own childhoods. Nothing seems to go right for Ralphie and we sympathize because nothing ever seems to go right for us either. Don't get the idea that this is a depressing movie though. The underlying message is tied together nicely by some genuinely funny moments, guaranteed real laughs. Aside from some language and very brief sexual humour, a great family film.

These words were muddered by Ralphie's father, only referred to as 'The Old Man' throughout the film. That alone is worth watching over and over and over.If you've never seen the Christmas Story, you haven't lived. This film appeals to everyone who ever wanted something so badly that they'd go way overboard just to get that point across. All he wants is that Red Rider Carboned action Air Rifle, and he makes it his point to get one from Santa.Ralphie and his friends are the center of the film, but i really think that the Old Man steals the show. His endless mutterings, yellings, and vengence tactics never get old. I feel like I'm 7 years old again everytime I see this. Except it would all be in Greek. If you haven't seen this movie, you must. Rent it and watch it with a group or just by yourself. It's 2 hours of endless fun.

reviews.review_title: folksy takedown of every Xmas cliché in the book
reviews.content: That's right, Bob Clark - director of Porky's and Black Christmas - helmed this modern holiday classic. And classic it is - but before it is anything else it is BROAD. Eyes roll, film speeds up constantly, dad talks in a high voice after he's bagged with a bowling ball. But it really works. Clark's nasty, cynical conventional wisdom is absolutely made for Jean Shepherd's folksy takedown of every Xmas cliché in the book. Every scene has a payoff, and it moves like slightly clunky lightning. Having just spent the holiday with a three-year-old I can confirm that this absolutely nails the childhood thing; Peter Billingsley deserves an Oscar, and the writers throw in familiar but underused types like Ralphie's absolutely unreadable brother and a terrifying bully-wimp by the utterly perfect name of Scott Farkus. And Clark's nervous neurosis about race is kept pretty much corked until the Chinese restaurant thing at the very end, where the wait staff sings carols with lots of gratuitous R's. Can't forgive that, but it doesn't ruin it. The Santa scene is as grotesque and terrifying as ever.

I'll admit Chirstmas at times I saw as a child as a time for freedom of choice. It's true this freedom was for the presents aspect but still it was exciting for me because it not just meant I could have anything I wanted (well OK not all things) but that it was based on my choice alone. This is my favorite Chirstmas film of all time and yes another childhood relic of mine that I seen when I was about nine and I still watch to this day.There really isn't much to say that hasn't already been said so I'll be brief. I really like the production value, they really make everything look like late 1940's small town America, the film almost looks like it could of been shot a long time ago which I feel give it an authentic feel.I like the narration by Jean Sheppard, it reminds me of the kind of narration I hear from the TV shows "The Wonder Years" and "The Adventures of Pete and Pete". Where it's gives the film a journalistic and personal sensibility.And I like the story which works because it's simplistic and really isn't much about anything. But what makes it work is that it has a Christmas atmosphere to it as well as good spirit. Despite all of the snafu that happen on the season they all still manage to have a wonderful Chirstmas.The characters are great, I really like Raphie's Dad played by the late Darren McGavin whom I remember from one of my favorite TV shows "Koljak the Night Stalker". This is my second favorite role from him he's a gruff, ruffled, but caring dad. He has a lot of great lines and I like that he's a guy that wants the best for both himself and his family which is something I can relate to cause who doesn't want the best. One of those things are of course that infamous erotic lamp.However my favorite character of course is Ralphie. His character I can really relate to because he's a lot like myself. I like the fact that he's kinda a writer as well as has an active imagination from the daydream sequences we see. Those sequences are really funny my favorite one is the cowboys and robbers scenario which almost looks like a light gun video game as Ralphie is dispatch Robbers whom are stationed at random places. But there also relatable because that's something we all do, sometimes if I'm really bored I imagine myself being and doing something else like being a Conan like hero slaying monsters or something. But just the simple fact that throughout the film he is trying to get the one thing he wants the most which is a Red Rider BB gun. We've all been there were there was that one thing we couldn't have for one reason or another. Now it's probably getting a video game that is Mature rated though for me it was always trying to watch a rated R action movie. And you really do feel pathos for the kid because he doesn't want that feeling of not getting what you really want for Christmas, no body does that's like eating a candy bar that you didn't really want to eat, it's not the same.And there are just lots of memorable comedic moments which are all the more funny because some of those situations can or have happened.From the infamous tongue sticking scene, what I found really funny about it wasn't so much the result but what lead to it which was the dreaded use of the dare word. It was pretty much a game of toughing the other out, I couldn't help but crack up when I saw the looks on everyones faces once the dare was delivered.However my favorite was the infamous Fudge scene which I find both hilarious and sad at the same time because there may have been a time or two where we might of had a slip up of the bad word.Well that's really all I can say, so Merry Christmas and to all a Good Night.Rating: 4 stars

I was encourage to watch this for the first time today (in 2011). It felt to me like an extended episode of Malcolm in the Middle. That's not necessarily a bad thing, but as a first time viewer it felt a little dated and I think everything it pioneered back in the day has been done better since.(I could also see it's possible influence on the comedy of the Farrelly Brothers - with the tongue on the flag pole (from Dumb and Dumber) and the fire, then police showing up to an embarrassing situation (from Something about Mary).)But overall, it might be time to retire this classic and let it live large in people's nostalgic memories.

reviews.review_title: A Christmas movie that always delights.
reviews.content: I've seen this picture about 4 or 5 times, and I just had the pleasure of watching it again on Turner Classic Movies. It remains as good as I remember it. A wonderful, very nostalgic view of Christmas through the eyes of an 8 year old. Everything - from "shoot your eyes out", the neighborhood dogs, the wonderful mother and father (and school teacher), the kids, the local bullies, the white Christmas, the small mid-western town, the concerns and fantasies of the kid hero, all add up to a great movie.

reviews.review_title: . . . Like watching French "Nihilism" and calling it "Joy to the World" !
reviews.content: Rather than watch this, I'd catch a French film on the "meaninglessness of life" . . . as it's the most Awful, non-redeeming Christmas Movie I've seen since I was a kid in the 50's ? Struggling with the current seasonal ads for 24 HRS. NON-STOP MARATHONS of TCS, I'm continually baffled that this movie, which focuses mainly on continual disappointment, sad outcomes, and cruelties (of life, kids & store Santas) is joyful or FUN to anybody other than people who love cruel jokes. When I saw it in the theaters, I came joyfully expectant, and left very depressed. If you're looking for a movie with a gentle spirit, inspiration, or any signs of the loving spirit that Christmas means . . . AVOID this if possible !!! I finally read through the IMDb comments and found LOTS of people hated this, also * . . . . while 95% + think it's the greatest movie there is! I'd rather stick myself with a cactus for 2 hrs . . . Oh well, another example for celebrating the variety of people on the planet !! As my Dad always said: Thankfully people DO like a variety of things . . . if they DIDN'T, everything I liked to do, would be so crowded when I got there, that there'd be no room for me !![. . . another happy city guy, with a small town boy inside *]
This is a very good Christmas film.  In tv guide this was number 2 on the Christmas list, if you ask me it should be one!

A Christmas Story is often seen as a great American Christmas classic and it was a film with a certain charm to it. It was a humorous film as a young boy prepares for Christmas, does what he can to get an air rifle for Christmas, try to avoid bullies, and generally suffer from the pitfalls of growing up. It was a film with a slight story, it was told from a child's perspective as he looked to get that BB gun. I didn't grow up with the film and I'm not American, so I don't have nostalgic feelings as some people would, but I still found it enjoyable. I can see how shows like The Goldbergs and Family Guy were influenced by this film.

reviews.review_title: The BB Gun is as American as a Norman Rockwell Saturday Evening Post Cover
reviews.content: I was not alive at the time this movie is set, but I can see that time moved more slowly in the mid 1900's than now, because in the 1950's where I grew up, there were two kinds of boys in the 9-11 year old range: those who wanted a Daisy air rifle...and those who had one.Is there anyone from that era whose mother didn't warn, "You'll shoot your eye out!"? I never had the Red Ryder model, but my parents did finally get me one Christmas the less expensive basic model, which as I recall, sold for $6.95. The Red Ryder model was about $3 more. As a minor point of trivia/goof not mentioned here at IMDb, the Red Ryder Carbine with a compass in the stock and a thing to tell time, never existed. The Red Ryder Carbine did not have those features, although another model of Daisy air rifle did.BTW, you can still by a Daisy Red Ryder Carbine many places including amazon.com. Yes, I bought one. The price has gone up.

This is a movie that I was late to. Part of it was that I heard people talking about how much of a classic it was. It was one that I had seen pieces of and knew different things, but never cared to watch it. That was until an ex-girlfriend of mine said how it was one of her favorite movies. We ended up watching for Christmas in July then. This second time watching it all the way through was with my in-laws on Christmas day since it either had been awhile for them or they watched it start to finish either.What I will say is that this is a solid movie. I don't love it, but part of that is lacking the nostalgia. It is interesting to see a look at one Christmas season in the life of Ralphie (Peter Billingsley), how quirky his family is and his pursuit to a Red Ryder Range 200 Shot BB gun. He lives with his mother, father and little brother Randy (Ian Petrella). His parents played by Melinda Dillon and Darren McGavin. He hangs out with is friends of Flick (Scott Schwartz) and Schwartz (R. D. Robb). They have to deal with bullies like Scut Farkus (Zack Ward) and his crony of Grover Dill (Yano Anaya). He also has to convince the adults around him that he can get this BB gun without shooting his eye out.It is a cute movie. I think that it does well in capturing the era well. It helps that the writer of the novel worked on the screenplay and even narrated as himself. This would be Jean Shepherd. I love the title of the novel being In God We Trust, All Others Pay Cash. It also wild that Bob Clark co-wrote the screenplay and directed it. I know him from the likes of Children Shouldn't Play with Dead Things, Porky's and one of the other quintessential Christmas horror movies in Black Christmas.As I was saying. This is well made. The use of soft focus with the cinematography helps capture a dreamlike quality. That makes sense for Ralphie remembering things. The acting is solid enough in giving these people life. I don't love this movie, but I can see why it is classic.My Rating: 7.5 out of 10.

What's all the hype about? The movie is like 15 storylines in one, all overseen by request fo a BB gun. I thought Ralphie was funny - but people think this movie is heart warming? The greatest holiday movie ever? No chance.

reviews.review_title: The greates Christmas movie ever made
reviews.content: "A Christmas Story" is by far the greatest Christmas movie ever made. It has such a great story line and it's a wonderful movie for kids to watch. I absolutely love this movie. It's always a delight to watch. Peter Billingsley played the part of Ralphie to perfection. And he was so cute! I loved watching him on screen. One of my favorite things about this movie was the dad's (Darren McGavin) obsession with the leg lamp. That was hilarious! And his reaction when it gets broken is unforgettable. He blamed it on his wife because she was "jealous of it". And the part where Ralphie beats up Flick (I think that's his name) after he's been mean to him for so long is so memorable. You almost can't blame Ralphie because I think we've all been there and felt the way he did! The ending was great. Ralphie finally got his Red Ryder BB gun! This is truly a classic and it shouldn't be missed by any Christmas movie fan. Thanks for reading my review!

reviews.review_title: It's about a lot more than a holiday.
reviews.content: This story is told from the vantage point of an ten year old boy. The boy is self-centered, willful, manipulative, in short, obnoxious. Everything in the story is about him. He is the center of his own personal universe. His likes his parents, but to him they are merely means through which to gain gratification. His father is a gruff sounding but caring and responsible working man; his mother is a house wife. The story provides little information about them. All that is known is learned from the boy, and his perceptions are limited. The movie ostensibly is a comedy. However , it pokes fun at the parents, who really aren't subjects who warrant derision. The story also takes shots at the crass materialism associated with Christmas. here, the story is more effective as a satire. It is difficult not to find something about Christmas that cannot be parodied. Already a cynic, the boy knows that it's all a bunch of baloney. All he wants is a certain present. He knows Santa won't be bringing it, so he is forced to use subterfuge to get his way. To find out what happens, watch the movie. But don't be fooled by the title. Although set during Christmas., this story is about a lot more than a holiday.

reviews.review_title: One of the WORST movies ever.
reviews.content: I don't understand how people say this is such a great movie. Not funny and very boring. Why TBS dedicates an entire 24 hours to this movie is beyond me.

reviews.review_title: A Classic for Christmas every year and a family film
reviews.content: One of the details that "A Christmas Story" gets right is the threat of having your mouth washed out with Lifebouy soap. Not any soap. Lifebouy. Never Ivory or Palmolive. Lifebouy, which apparently contained an ingredient able to nullify bad language. Ralphie's life is made a misery by that danger. He finds that nobody in northern Indiana (not his mother, not his teacher, not even Santa Claus) is able to even think about a BB gun without using the words "shoot your eye out." At one point in the movie, in a revenge daydream, he knocks on his parents' door with dark glasses, a blind man's cane and a beggar's tin cup. They are shocked, and ask him tearfully what caused his blindness, and he replies coolly, "Soap poisoning." The movie is not only about Christmas and BB guns, but also about childhood, and one detail after another rings true. The school bully, who, when he runs out of victims, beats up on his own loyal sidekick. The little brother who has outgrown his snowsuit, which is so tight that he walks around looking like the Michelin man; when he falls down he can't get up. "A Christmas Story" was released in the Christmas season of 1983, and did modest business at first (people don't often go to movies with specific holiday themes). It got warm reviews and two Genie Awards (the Canadian Oscars) for Bob Clark's direction and for the screenplay. And then it moved onto home video and has been a stealth hit season after season, finding a loyal audience. In a poignant way, "A Christmas Story" records a world that no longer quite exists in America. Kids are no longer left unattended in the line for Santa. The innocence of kids' radio programs has been replaced by slick, ironic children's programming on TV. The new Daisy BB guns have a muzzle velocity higher than that of some police revolvers, and are not to be sold to anyone under 16. Nobody knows who Red Ryder was, let alone that his sidekick was Little Beaver. So much has been forgotten. There is a moment when the Old Man needs an answer for the contest he is entering. The theme of the contest is "Characters in American Literature," and the question is: "What was the name of the Lone Ranger's nephew's horse?"

reviews.review_title: For this time of year, you can't do better!
reviews.content: Every time I need to make Christmas more "Christmas like" I pop this one in, sit back and...LAUGH! LAUGH! and LAUGH!I mean, the part where he envisions taking out Black Bart, The Leg Lamp, Scut, The Furnace...it just goes on and on!Not to mention the Red Ryder!You got so many side stories that you can attach to in this movie. And the way the all play out, you just know they're gonna end in hysterics.So if you feel like your Christmas doesn't have enough entertainment, sit down, alone or with friends, and watch this!

TBS airs this movie for a full day every year on Christmas, and my family always gathers around after dinner to watch it at least once.Peter Billingsley plays Ralphie, a young man who desperately wants a BB gun for Christmas. The movie follows his life in the run-up to Christmas, showing Ralphies comically overactive imagination and daydreams as he schemes to earn his BB gun and then fantasizes about how great his life would be if he owned one. Along the way the movie looks at Ralphie's family and friends and visits the everyday absurdity of suburban life.The humor is easy and comfortable, like a beloved old pair of socks that your know-nothing girlfriend wants you to throw away (hmmph). I know they're getting old and threadbare but darn it all if I don't like to pull them out of the drier and get lazy around the house in them anyway. I don't know if that made any sense. :) What I mean is that I've seen the movie a dozen times already, and know all the jokes practically by heart, but I always laugh anyway when I watch it. That's the kind of movie it is; funny, family friendly, and just plain fun. Highly recommended during the holidays.

This film was not what I expected at all! I hadn't heard of it but thought I would give it a go as it scored highly on IMDb. It's a collection if funny memories with no apparent linkage between them - so random! I loved the oh fudge moment, the prize floor lamp in the shape of a sexy leg (and the fact the dad thought he had won a bowling alley),the bullying scenes ( where his brother was always running behind) and the look on the kids face all the time! Also loved the 'you'll shoot your eye out' running joke and the kid getting his tongue stuck to the lamp post. The best thing about this film is that the events are seen through the rose tinted glasses of a young child. The bullying, the soap in the mouth, the theme essay it has no connection and is just as a kid would remember it. Very different to anything I have seen, and definitely in a good way!

reviews.review_title: Let's give Leigh Brown (Shepherd's wife) the credit for this movie that is due her.
reviews.content: Few know the story behind the film A Christmas STORY.Jean, like most writers, (and I was his editor and indeed Leigh's too for several books) was not the best critic of his writing. He produced ideas and monologue material like an inexhaustible artesian well, but seldom knew which of them were the most salable. Like many artists he was always in love with the last thing he created.Despite sellout shows at Carnegie Hall and elsewhere and a top rated talk radio show, Jean never made a lot of money out of his writing. And the best media use of his talents was a remarkable WGBH series he wrote and produced called "Jean Shepherd's America" some of which is available on a DVD.Jean's producer for his public appearances and his radio show was a remarkable woman named Leigh Brown. Leigh had been a show jumper at competitive horse show on the circuit for years and had more broken bones and fewer teeth than any pretty blonde I knew. But her funny bone was in great shape and her sense for Jean's most commercial work was shrewd as well.Anyone who wanted to extract something salable from Jean quickly learned to go through Leigh.She had always believed that several stories in IN GOD WE TRUST (including the Red Ryder BB gun story) would make a Christmas feature that would run every Christmas for years to come and finally make some real money for Jean.She was right and they were finally able to retire to Sanibel island. And her co-authorship of A Christmas STORY was probably the key to finding the best material for the film easily. Had Bob Clark tried to work with Jean directly, chances are the film would never have been finished.

reviews.review_title: Not funny, minutely related to Christmas
reviews.content: The language (cursing) by the father is appalling; he acts like a belligerent drunk throughout most of the movie. The mother is a half wit. Just an all around bad movie. Despite the glowing reviews, our entire family (2 adults, 4 children) detested this movie. It was a unanimous decision.Plus, the outline of Cleveland but it is based near Chicago? Also, some lewd material (the lamp) and bloody scenes (fight). We were very disappointed since we looked forward to seeing this movie based on recommendations. My advice, if you are looking for a nice family holiday movie look elsewhere.Terrible movie.

I wish I could remember the first time I saw this movie, I am guessing it was late 80's, but whenever the year was that was the year "A Christmas Story" became my favorite Christmas movie. Odd since it is a movie about a young boy in the late 40's and I grew up in the 70's. But it resonates so strongly with myself and my wife. This movie is so warm and genuine... and funny. To me it captures a unique time in American history and there are very few movies that provide a better slice of Americana. I could always relate to Ralphie, now that I am 36 with 3 kids I can relate with the Dad as well.This movie is not some cinematic masterpiece, the acting is perfect but not Oscar quality, I gave it an 8 out of 10 but mind you I rarely give 9s. The best endorsement I can give is that this was one of the first DVDs I bought and is now tradition to watch it the first weekend after Thanksgiving, uninterrupted and without commercials.

reviews.review_title: I Can't Understand All the Hype about this Movie???
reviews.content: I had never seen this movie, so tonight we went to the video store to look for a Christmas movie & I saw this so my wife & I agreed to rent it.HONESTLY, I do not understand all the hype about this movie. The entire movie was STUPID!!! Stupid kids, stupid parents (what parent would order a lamp shaped like a leg of a playboy bunny??? What example is that to set for their kids!!!) The teacher was disgusting!!! What parent would tell their kid to eat their food like a pig!!! I am sorry, but this film did nothing at all for me or my wife!!! P.S: Usually my wife & me disagree about movies; If I like it she dislikes it & vise-versa. But this one we both agreed was not worth our time!!!

reviews.review_title: The Greatest Christmas Movie Ever Made!
reviews.content: "A Christmas Story" is without a doubt, the greatest Christmas story ever made.  It invoked nostalgic memories of life in the 1940's, induced side-splitting humor, and has become an icon in our Christmas repertoire!  This is one of those movies that my mom and I always quote, always remember, and will never forget!  And although there are plenty of good Christmas films out there, they are no match for this one.  Don't even rent it, buy it and put it in a place of honor!
A Christmas Story is, plain and simple, an enjoyable film. It's not particularly smart or impressive.

I Have watched this movie every Christmas eve and Christmas day since it came out in 83(I was 8) and I love it dearly I hope the networks don't stop showing it because it is a true Christmas tradition in my house(and Others) to watch it with my children and hopefully with their children. Many families have grown to love this movie throughout the year and just like mine have a steady tradition of watching "A Christmas Story" every Christmas for as long as it keeps showing. it is enjoyable to see Ralphie and the gang just having their fun and seeing him get what he wants and then does exactly what his mother told him-shooting his eye out. This movie is so funny and enjoyable to watch

reviews.review_title: A classic but it's not perfect
reviews.content: I grew up watching this film every Christmas so u do like it and will always watch it every year but it's not my fav holiday film. The dream scenes are Dreedfull I fast forward them every time I watch the film. What ms great about the film is the heart it has and the nostalgic is fun.

A Christmas Story is one of those simple, obviously Christmas themed 'heartwarming movies', but not in a sappy or annoying way. It's very wry in its humor and at times it borders on black-comedy. Such as the high point of the film with the not so jolly mall Santa Clause.When discussing the cast of this film first and foremost you must address what a good job Peter Billingsley and his adolescent costars did here. But beyond them is the supporting adult cast who know the parts they're playing and of course there's Darren McGavin who seems thoroughly enjoying himself in this silly character.The film is proof that stakes really don't matter if you're execution is done right as it makes a compelling story out of a nine year old wanting a bb gun for Christmas-while also being hilarious. And director Bob Clark does a first rate job layering the film with style which is not just simply there but actually enhances the story and overall movie.

Ralphie's journey from wishes to a Red Ryder BB gun is long, arduous, and filled with disappointment. On the way he navigates the adventures and pitfalls of childhood, and watches those his parents meet on the road of life.But the one scene I'll never forget from the FIRST time I watched the movie was the visit to Santa. The end of that encounter was a punch line I never expected, and I laughed out loud when I saw it. I only wish I could experience it that way every time I see the movie.The slice of life moments in the rest of the film are humorous and ring true to so many of us. My brother once stuck his tongue to something in our refrigerator's freezer and got it stuck. Luckily my sister thought to pour cold water on it. Perfect solution, and I'll never understand how with teachers and fire men on the scene, no one thought of that solution for poor Flick. :-)

reviews.review_title: One of Those Flicks I Never Tire of Watching.....!
reviews.content: It hits on all cylinders as far as childhood memories go, folks. Everyone can take something away from this movie: the problem with childhood bullies, desperately wanting some toy that seemed like a big deal back then ---- and everybody has tried to suck-up to the teacher in the hopes that it would make life easier at home! This movie puts a skewed and funny spin on what is normally not pleasant. We can all laugh at the characters and ourselves.Nobody else could have played the dad like Darren McGavin, an old favorite for many audiences.Favorite quote from the movie - Darren McGavin: 'He looks like a deranged Easter bunny....a pink nightmare!' (Ralphie modelling his aunt's homemade present of a cute bunny costume..)Favorite moment: when years of humiliation, fear and a feeling of being short-changed by life finally come to a head, and Ralphie gets angry and beats up the neighborhood bully. And doesn't get in trouble for it, either. A rite of passage, or sorts....As a woman who enjoys her food, I would have taken a sawed-off shotgun to the Buttkuses'(?) unruly hounds after they made off with that turkey. I would have acted very differently from just quietly settling for Chinese dinner on a major holiday, let me tell you... PETA could go jump in the lake. I'm glad that some stations have marathon showings of 'A Christmas Story' during the holiday season. This has become very common with a lot of networks: like SCI-FI channel's marathon showing of 'Twilight Zone' from New Year's Eve to New Year's Day.

reviews.review_title: Something to warm your heart over the cold seasons.
reviews.content: Being British, we miss America's favourite festive treat A Christmas Story. I know it runs 24 hours on Christmas Day over there but here it has no presence or significance whatsoever. However, that doesn't mean it doesn't work. The irreverent vignettes of a childhood in hindsight are identifiable no matter where you're from or how old you are. The events it details occurred nearly 80 years ago and that distance makes the film keep its bite. It's an imaginative film and it's got personality. It mostly stems from its unconventional and sardonic narration of the young boy grown up who becomes our guide. The contrast gives the characterisation a strange effect, especially when it slips into present tense. Ralphie's meandering ordeals are for the most part entertaining, but the film suffers and cheapens when it opts for cartoony moments of fantasy. It could work with better execution, and although they're amusing, it's disjointed. Nevertheless, I didn't realize how many iconic scenes, moments and props came from this film so I guess that fills up a pop culture meter for me. While its nostalgia only goes so far and it doesn't seem to have the ambition to take its emotional shards to a more powerful place opting for a distraction instead, I can definitely see why audiences over the years have fallen for its smirking charm.7/10

A Christmas Story is just wonderful, and having the ability to watch it every holiday season might be the best Christmas gift I could ask for, my grandpa knew what he was doing showing me this at a young age, and it's tied with the brilliant Home Alone for my favorite Christmas movie ever.A Christmas Story tells one of the funniest holiday tales ever, it's a marvelously hilarious film, with loads of slapstick comedy and tons of clever writing, Peter Billingsley is such a joy to watch as his character tries so hard to get the one gift he always wanted, with perfectly accompanying side characters and a truly beautiful ending.The ending realization is everything, that old man Parker was the only one listening to what Ralphie truly wanted.I don't know why I love this movie so much, I just do, a Christmas Story is tied with home alone for the best Christmas film ever made, and it gets an A+

reviews.review_title: Second Favorite after Monty Python and the Holy Grail
reviews.content: This movie has been a part of my life since I first saw it in 1985. When HBO showed it, I must have seen bits and pieces of it at least ten times. It has become my second favorite movie after Monty Python and the Holy Grail.What makes this movie funny is not so much the situations, but how they are done in a grandiosely exaggerated fashion. We've all seen department store Santa Clauses, but how many were perched on a gilded throne? The sarcasm and wit are an acquired taste--sort of like Lux.This movie takes everyday monotony's, such as eating meatloaf, and turns them into comedy.

A Christmas Story is becoming the It's a Wonderful Life of the Baby Boomer generation... maybe more so for the Tweener Generationa designation I just made up for folks born between, say, 1930 and 1946. The movie is especially meaningful for those who were boys in the context of a loving family where Pop worked, Mom kept house (and kept you out of trouble), and the Popsicle Index [1] was nearly 100%.
