reviews.review_title: Always a welcome addition to Christmas joy...
reviews.content: Heck, A Christmas Story has become a Christmas classic, in the same category as It's A Wonderfull Life and Miracle On 34th Street. It allows us to reflect on just the magic while letting us forget for a moment just how hard life can be growing up...A Christmas Story also encourages us to laugh at ourselves as we watch Ralphie's antics in the pursuit of the crown jewel of Christmas presents for a young boy in the 40's. The movie does something else that more modern ones don't...we can escape reality for two hours of pure entertainment...

This is a real classic - a truly hilarious movie. There are some parts I'll relate here for those who have seen this movie. Those who have not, go see it this Christmas (it runs for 24 hours straight!).****SPOILERS! DON"T READ!****The overblown narration. Look magazine. Triple dog dare. Lifeboy. Fudge. Bumpus! Santa's boot coming down (favorite moment in the entire movie!). Electric sex. "I can't put my arms down!" The tone that plays whenever Ralphie's dreams are dashed: WA-WAAHH! Chinese turkey.And that's just what I remember. And Christmas was 3 months ago.

The one movie that people have been watching every Christmas(at least here in America) since the year it came out is A Christmas Story. The movie is about a little kid named Ralph who wants nothing more for Christmas than a Red Rider Bee Bee Gun. He goes to a lot of lengths to try and convince his parents to buy him one, but the common response is that he'll shoot his eye out. He tries everything, writing an essay, asking the mall Santa but even Santa says he'll shoot his eye out. The movie focuses on a few more things though. One of the subplots is a bully that pesters Ralph and his friends constantly and another is Ralph's Dad winning a contest and getting a lamp shaped like a woman's leg that his Mom despises. It centered around the viewpoint of Ralph too, so things are sometimes exaggerated in his mind. Any little boy might also recognize some of the fantasies going through his head. Most of the things that happen in the movie could happen any time of the year, not just Christmas. But that's the appeal. It's not a cohesive plot it's just a kid living his life and leading up to the days before Christmas. It's hilarious, it's well made, I watch it every year and I recommend it to everyone else.

reviews.review_title: Loving attention to detail, handled with care.
reviews.content:
Who would have thought Bob Clark, the man behind a list of trashy and forgotten horror and teen sex comedies from the 70's and 80's, had it in him to bring this adorable Christmas tale to the screen with barely a flaw. There are very few films made in the past 2 decades or so which have been able to capture the nuance and detail of the 1940's so as to make you feel as though you were actually transported back to that period.  This, along with Woody Allen's Radio Days, is the quintessential example.I had actually avoided seeing this movie back in the early 80's BECAUSE of Bob Clark's involvement, not seeing it until Christmas '86 on Television. Needless to say I was instantly charmed and it's been part of my Christmas viewing every year since.People who hated it and registered negative comments here to do with lack of plot etc just don't get it.  It's a filmed memoir with comedic trappings and as such all the set pieces happening around Little Ralphie's quest to obtain a his Red Ryder BB Gun speaks more volumes than any three act contrived plot could possibly have done.It's all about detail, those affectionate things from the past which fleet past in everyone's life no matter the decade.  I am a child of the the 60's but the 40's have always held a fascination for me.  Things that are sprinkled around in this film, if you care to notice them, ring true from Bing Crosby and the Andrews Sisters on the radio to Little Orphan Annie to Look Magazine, to the Wizard of Oz characters, to the cars and trucks on the street to the snow, which even manages to look 40's.  It's Christmas as if Rockwell had painted it.But the nuances aren't only visual.  Peter Billingsley registers what must be one of the 10 most effective and affecting performances in movie history. The story needed just the right kid to play the part or else it might have fallen flat.  Just any kid wouldn't have done and Billingsley proves that some things are just destined.  The whole cast in fact is simply perfect and give memorable performances.Amongst the lighthearted sequences, there are still a couple more touching moments which are handled gently and are quite moving.  The whole scene after Ralphie snaps and whoops on the bully, and is led home by his mom rings truth in every way, from his kid brother hiding under the sink, to Ralphie's very real dread of being punished for his use of foul language. Gen Y kids will of course find this ludicrous as they pretty much come out of the birth canal these days uttering those kind of expletives, but back when I was a kid even in the 70's we didn't get away any easier than kids in the old days for swearing within earshot of adults.The payoff scene where Ralphie finally gets his much sought after Red Ryder rifle, while his dad glows, slipping back into his own childhood for a brief moment, is simply priceless.Aside from maybe the slightly overdone Santa Claus scene there is nothing in this story I would change.  It's the only Christmas movie produced theatrically in the last 50 years which can be regarded as a classic. Other lame and half-hearted efforts like Prancer, Santa Claus the Movie, and the recent The Grinch have done nothing to capture the magic of Christmas.  
A Christmas Story stands alongside the greats - It's a Wonderful Life, The Bishop's Wife, the original Miracle on 34th Street, and Alastair Sim's version of a Christmas Carol.  A must-see holiday gem.

A Christmas story is a definite Christmas classic. Ralphie Parker (Peter Billingsley) is an 8 year old kid in the 1940s who wishes for a Red Ryder BB gun for Christmas. His mother (Melinda Dillon) tells him that he'll shoot his eye out. During the Christmas season plenty of other things happen. Ralphie's dad (Darren McGavin) get's a leg lamp as a major award (which breaks later on), Ralphie's friend Flick (Scott Schwartz) get's his tongue stuck to a flagpole, and Raplhie get's in trouble for saying "the word". With all of it's underage swearing, it's mean mall Santa, and such memorable characters, this rightly became a classic. And hey, I'm writing this on Christmas Eve so I'm going to go watch it right now. If you haven't seen it then make a habit of watching this one every Christmas.

I have seen this film literally dozens of times over the past 20+ years and I STILL find myself laughing out loud throughout it! It is a joy...a treat...an incredible period piece of what Christmas was like when I grew up (although the time of this movie predates me by about 10 years as I grew up in the 50s and not the 40s as in A Christmas Story).Darren McGavin is brilliant as the father...a masterful performance as the befuddled Dad obsessed by his furnace and the smelly hound dogs next door! Peter Billingsly is terrific as Ralphie in his quest for the perfect gift, a Red Ryder air rifle...his daydream sequences are wonderful...seriously, haven't you done JUST as he does when YOU were a little kid? Watch it, enjoy it and have a MERRY CHRISTMAAS!!!!

In 1962, when I was about 7 - the same age as Ralphie, I was hooked on THE ABSENT MINDED PROFESSOR and the flying Model T Ford. Totally absorbed but my father, in a way very much like the wonderful scene with the OLD MAN and the BB Gun gift, gave me about as a good. Downstairs in the garage, the last present, was a 1/2 scale Model T, one of the ones you see at Shriner's parades. I have a photograph taken about an hour later of me in the car, totally gone just like Ralphie loading the BBGun. And yes, I drove it instantly into a snowbank. That one scene though, when the Old Man, and McGavin was never better, resonates with me through and through. I KNOW THAT MOMENT. Every parent who gives his child the One PRESENT the son or daughter is dying for knows that moment. Never better.Any Christmas, sit down with this movie and your family, enjoy nice red wine in front of the tree and smile and remember when we all believed in Reindeer and the sounds on the roof.

This is another good christmas film along with Home Alone and The Grinch. The films about Ralphie's desire for a red ryder BB Gun. But everyone keeps telling him you'll shoot your eye out. Two bullies are always chasing Ralphie and his friends home. Ralphie keeps checking the mailbox to see if his decoder pen has come yet. When they take Ralphie to see Santa at the mall he asks Santa for a Red Ryder BB Gun and Santa tells him the same thing In fact Ralphie even got a C+ on his paper for writing about his desire for a Red Ryder BB Gun. In fact Ralphie's BB Gun causes him to fall on the ground and crack his glasses. Ralphie's friend Flick sticks his tongue to a pole all in all this a good Christmas film.

reviews.review_title: The Best Profanity-free Movie of All Time.
reviews.content: No movie has ever captured that subtle balance between childish innocence and greed so well.  This is a real American family, not the saints of Yesteryear's hollywood or the dysfunctional fools of most of today's popular entertainment.How can you not rejoice when he opens that Rifle?I think the most salient aspect is the way Ralphie speaks of his father. He knows all his idiosyncrasies (An Oldsmobilseman, an artist who works in profanity, the only human being that the blood hounds pay attention to, his flat tire times, his fuse changing, his contest entering).  It's the kind of things that men learn to appreciate about their Dad's.  When I was a kid my dad used to write letters to every newspaper on the planet to make sure they listed Frankie Laine's birthday.  Seemed such a strange thing for a grown man to do.  Now I post my movie commentary on web sites that no one will ever read.  It's comforting to know there's an origin to this kind of behavior.  I wonder what Papa did back in Vilnius?

reviews.review_title: A Good Christmas film but didn't think it was classic like people say it is
reviews.content: A Christmas Story was a neat film with good Christmas humor. The kids of the movie were great especially that bully red-haired kid with that racoon tail on his head. He was hilarious and the narrator was good at narrating. He had a good voice fit for the movie. In some ways, I just don't think this movie is a classic. My parents say it's one of the greatest holiday movies ever but I just don't think that. I thought half of the movie was very boring and the other half was funny. Maybe I'm wrong but I didn't think the film was extremely special. I mean it was good but far from a classic. 6.5/10
Nothing is better than sitting on the couch on Christmas Day and watching this movie. There's a reason why this has a 24 hr loop on Christmas. Nothing will ever beat it.

reviews.review_title: Other than being a classic it has very little to offer
reviews.content: Okay I know a lot of people are going to hate this review, but I honestly do not understand what is so enjoyable about this movie. The movie is pretty much a Christmas special marathon with many mini story arcs going like a Christmas special. While this certainly does give the movie a Christmas feel and a "classic" feel that doesn't make it a good movie. Let me explain more in depth:What does the movie offer that makes it good? Is it laugh out loud funny? No, it is humorous I'll give it that but humorous because of its nostalgia factor. Is it original? No not really. Does it have strong character development? No. Does it have terrific acting? It has okay acting with average dialogue. Does it have an interesting or complex plot? No. And this is what bugs me about this movie: NOTHING happens in the movie that is of any importance. The movie ends where it begins with nothing being accomplished. So is the movie a classic? Sure I guess you can call it a classic because most movies that are classics are cheesy. Is it entertaining? Yes mildly so. The movie is successful in the fact that it feels like a Christmas special and does portray the hecticness of Christmas fairly well. But then why would I watch a movie that is portraying why Christmas can be annoying? I have no idea.An okay movie but it isn't really special, innovative, funny, or really clever. It's average.

List all the classic American Christmas movies and they're pretty much all well known in the UK. Classics here too, shown every year. For whatever reasons, this is one that just slipped through the net here. I don't ever recall seeing it on tv growing up. I'd be surprised if it was never shown, it probably just doesn't air much because nobody has ever heard of it. I only saw it for the first time a few years ago, on a streaming service. I was amazed that here was a really popular 1980s Christmas movie, yet i'd never even heard of it!It doesn't really resonate with me as much as it no doubt does to many Americans, but it's a fun watch. Not sure when exactly it is set, i'd guess sometime around the 1940s. I suspect the main reason it wasn't shown here much (if at all) is the story revolving around a BB gun. I think BB guns were a "thing" here during WW2, i've seen tv and movies set here around then where kids were playing wit them, but probably were frowned upon in the 1980s if not actually illegal. We're all used to hunters (Elmer Fudd etc) having guns, a 9 year old kid with a gun is probably a step too far for family tv. Of course, it could also just be that nobody here eats meatloaf, uses lifebuoy soap or about a hundred other things referenced that are almost completely American. It's hard enough to get nostalgic about things that stopped being a thing 30 years before you were born, but even harder when they've never been a thing in your country ever!Whatever the reasons, it's a bit of a shame this film is largely unheard of here. Be sure to drink your ovaltine is hilarious. No idea if that was an actual thing, but it's the type of dirty lowdown trick companies play on kids! Raise your hopes for something exciting, oh..it;s just a crummy commercial! It's truly epic when Ralphie beats up the bully. I can definitely get behind that. Some people, even kids, deserve a good bit of karma.

reviews.review_title: This isn't a Christmas movie. It is an overrated anti-Christmas Movie
reviews.content: If anything this is an overrated anti-Christmas film. It is not funny. It is depressing. It's whole reason for being seams to cater to people who are so frustrated with the pressure of the Holidays that they want to blow off steam by flipping around and mock the whole holiday scene. For that is what it does. It mocks every holiday tradition in sight. The characters are despicable and insensitive. The only things I could relate to is the washing out the mouth with soap as punishment for saying a swear word and the decoder ring because that happened to me. Otherwise the story is blatantly unbelievable. A nine year old kid who still believes in Santa Claus? A grandmother who still knits a full body bunny suit pajamas for a nine year old child but not for his younger brother? Those type of pajamas are for toddlers and infants. No sane person would make them for a kids even at the age of six. But yet we are led to believe that the grandmother is so senile that she still thinks Ralphie is still 6 years old when he is nine in the movie. How about the parents stepping in to tell the grandmother to stop making those pajamas because the kid is too old for them and she is embarrassing him. That would be the realistic thing to do. But do they in this film? No. They seam to enjoy embarrassing their own son by forcing him to wear them. Or how believable is it to have a nine year child still going to a department store Santa, sitting on his lap and ask for a BB. Gun? Not very. Worst yet, no department or mall would ever allow their Santa to put his foot in the face of a child to push him down a slide. They would have faced a ton of law suits. Another absolutely unbelievable part of the film was Darren McGavin as the father "The Old Man - Mr. Parker". He was way too old to be married to Melinda Dillon "Mrs. Parker" and still be called a young couple in the film. He looks like should be having Grandchildren or Great-grandchildren instead of his first round of offspring. Yes, I understand this story is presented through the distorted lens of a child viewing his parents as old. I just think that if you can spot the dye in McGavin's hair, the director carried the exaggeration to far and broke the willing suspension of disbelief. I never bought for a moment McGavin as being the father in that family. The mother is not that much better. A woman who has a husband who has swear words pouring out of his mouth freely as water flowing over the edge of Niagara falls but yet is shocked when one of her sons eventually starts using the same language he had picked up from his father. Come on! Even Though nonsense words are substituted for the real swear words, it is clear what was really meant that the father was saying and what Ralphie was saying. The F word and it is not "Fudge". The father doesn't think his foul mouth isn't partly the blame? Also the bit of the mother separating the two boys fighting but not stopping to see if one boy is alright when she sees that one boy has a bloody nose was a bit far-fetched. How many mothers you know act like that? Not many. Ralphie was just plainly stupid. He should have known better at his age not to swear in front of his parents. Here is another piece of stupidity by Ralphie. After being told how dangerous BB rifles were and was told not to place the target in front of a metal surface because BBs ricochet off of metal, what does he do? He places the target on a lattice in front of a metal fence where the BB goes through the target, through the lattice and hits the metal fence and ricochets back and hits Ralphie in the glasses on the first shot. As for the story and the jokes, the story was predictable and the many of the jokes were ether not funny, or just plain flat. Every plot point was televised a mile ahead of time. I mean I knew from the from almost the start that Ralphie was going to get his BB. rifle and shoot his eye out in the end. I knew the tongue was going to stick to the flagpole. I knew that the mother was somehow going destroy the leg lamp. As far as the leg lamp gag went, that was not that funny in the first place and got old faster than a particle traveling at the speed of light. The story is so bereft of content that a group of animators made a 30 second parody of it that covers every important point in the story. If the story can be condensed into 30 seconds, it means that there is not that much content in it in the first place. That can be viewed at http://www.angryalien.com/aa/xmas_storybuns.asp .Oh, what a lovely messages this film sends out. Like, for instamce, if you get in trouble blame, it is okey to it on a totally innocent kid in order to get yourself out of trouble. Or how about that mean Santa Claus so much wants to get rid of kids that he will put his foot in your face. Wow, I would just love my kids to see that. NOT!

reviews.review_title: The Best Christmas Movie Ever Made!!! (And I Thought "Christmas Vacation" Was Funny)
reviews.content: Christmas with a typical American family in the 1940's - what an excellent plot!  This movie is hysterically funny!  It will make you laugh throughout the whole time!  I shows how children were, especially boys, were like back then in the 1940's, and how American families were with a touch of humor! This movie is good for the whole family to watch! :o)

reviews.review_title: A Christmas film to watch every December
reviews.content: A quarter of a century has passed since the 1983 release of A Christmas Story. However, I didn't see the movie until a few years later, when I watched it on television. A Christmas Story is a classic. It is one of those many great Christmas films that should be viewed every year in December.Ralph (played by Peter Billingsley) wants a Red Ryder BB gun for Christmas, but he is constantly told that he would get his eye shot out. Even the department store Santa Claus agreed. None of this, however, could discourage Ralph from getting such an item, as he would finally receive it on Christmas morning.All of the principal cast members did a great job in their respective roles, especially the late Darren McGavin, who played Ralph's father. McGavin died in 2006, but he is immortalized in all of his acting work, especially in this movie.

reviews.review_title: I liked it at first, but now.....
reviews.content: First, I'll introduce myself as a Shepherd "fathead," an avid admirer of his work. OK. I also saw ACS as among the 17 at its theatrical release--my girlfriend and I were the audience. I enjoyed the film then, but don't care if I ever see it again, especially after seeing again recently THE PHANTOM OF THE OPEN HEARTH, the first film version of Shep's stories. Darren McGavin chews the wallpaper as The Old Man, whereas James Broderick brings out the character spot-on in PHANTOM, doing more with a hard look than McGavin's "NOT A FINGER!!!!" I don't know what the deal was with Melinda Dillon's hairstyle--she looked more like Diane Keaton on a bad day and hardly made me forget Barbara Bolton as Ralph's mom. Shep later said he wanted a more sardonic, anti-nostalgic edge to ACS akin to his stories, complete with out-of-tune music in spots (which PHANTOM used to the right effect)--too bad that got muted. It's worth a look, sure, but it won't make me forget Shep's Christmas Eve reading of the original Red Ryder story ("Duel in the Snow, or Red Ryder Nails the Cleveland Street Kid") on WOR, let alone PHANTOM. Excelsior, you fatheads, and FLICK LIVES!

reviews.review_title: AFTER THE 100TH SHOWING THIS YEAR, IT LOSES SOMETHING
reviews.content: I like "A Christmas Story", but I don't give it the cult endorsement so many tend to around the holidays. It has become a little watered down because it is shown so many times during the Christmas season. Some stations even have "A Christmas Story" marathon.  It is a pleasant little holiday movie showing us a window on the 1940's. I felt Darren McGavin was a little annoying as the father, and the mother Melinda Dillon was a bit too ditsey. Peter Billingsley had a cherubic face which helped sell alot of the scenes. The best part of the movie for me was the narrator, Jean Shepherd. His voice was perfect, and had a comedic tone to it throughout the movie. His voice-overs were well written, and the narration gave "A Christmas Story" a uniqueness. Being set at Christmas time doesn't hurt either.

I laugh like crazy every time I see A Christmas Story. All the actors playing the family are priceless! Who will ever forget classic scenes like the leg lamp, the demented Santa at the store, the kid sticking his tongue on the frozen pole, Ralphie getting a C on his Red Ryder BB gun essay, etc? But the most telling scene, I think, is where Ralphie discovers the truth about the decoder thing. Another childhood fantasy shattered.Put this in your holiday film must see list with National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation, Home Alone 1 & 2, Miracle on 34th Street and It's A Wonderful Life. You'll love it.

"A Christmas Story" is one of the funniest Christmas movies ever made. It's also a Christmas movie with a heart. The story revolves around a young boy named Ralphie who desperately wants a Red Rider BB gun for Christmas. However when he tells his mother this, she immediately says "No. You'll shoot your eye out." This is only the beginning for Ralphie, who ends up having a Christmas holiday he'll never forget. It's hard to believe that the director of the smash sex comedy "Porky's" (Bob Clark) directed this, and it's even more hard to believe what a terrific job he did. This is far and away Clark's best film. "A Christmas Story" is wonderfully told and beautifully acted. Peter Billingsley is the whole show here as Ralphie in one of the best film performances by a child actor. Melinda Dillon ("Close Encounters of the Third Kind" and "Harry and the Hendersons") is very good as Ralphie's mother. But the real scene stealer is Darren McGavin, who's a hoot as Ralphie's father. Just get a load of the way McGavin delivers his dialogue at times throughout this movie. His obscenities had me in stitches. A few preposterously silly moments here and there can't ruin this movie. "A Christmas Story" is definitely a Christmas movie classic for all-time.
***1/2 (out of four)

I finally got the video last Christmas! My brother and I like the story because it reminds us of growing up in Evanston, IL in the 1950's. Same kinds of folks, sames kinds of issues.Plus, I cheered when he beat us Farkus, since I was always bullied when I was a child! The sequel "A Summer Story" is also worth watching!Love the scene in the Chinese restaurant.The ongoing commentary by Jean Shephard himself is worth the movie too!Belongs up there with "It's A Wonderful Life" and "A Charlie Brown Christmas!"Also, who can forget the scene when Flick gets his tongue stuck to the flagpole?If you did not grow up during the baby-boomer's, it is probably hard to identify with this movie, but watch it anyway!

reviews.review_title: A Classic at every age, and I don't use that word lightly
reviews.content: When I was a kid in the 90s, school would come to a standstill for this movie. It would follow us around from class to class on TNT, where they would proudly boast "a week of 24/7 Christmas Story's!" Followed, of course, by a week of "It's a Wonderful Life". From the very opening scenes "I can't put my arms down!!" to the classic "You'll shoot your eye out, kid!" Everyone has heard the classic scenes in different movies, and various pop culture references. What is amazing is this movie still...amazes! My father was blown away that we could watch it in color. "I only have seen this movie in black and white!" I distinctly remember a cold winters day in 1993, where we popped in the VHS and watched it in color. My dad had a huge, childlike grin on his face the entire time. Should you watch this movie? Absolutely. You should show it to your children, and your grandchildren. I expect it'll still be a classic for many years to come. J

"You'll shoot your eye out".The story is about a young boy is insistent on getting Red Ryder BB Gun for Christmas while he puts up with his family during the holidays in the 1940's. A Christmas Story is been known as a Christmas classic to everyone. The movie started off has a small budget film suddenly turning into a big hit years later, even got a squeal which I reviewed and yeah it wasn't pretty and I had a lot to say about that film, so anywhere I can clearly see why people are calling this a classic because in my heart it is.I said this in my past reviews about annoying narrating in movies. I just don't like how a character can narrator though out the film, just freaking speak, but in this movie it didn't annoy me, it actually worked for the film, because Ralphie (Main character) put a mans voice in his head just to sound cool and that is just what a kid would do, oh and he also day dreams, just like a kid.The good thing in this movie: The character's in this movie are so funny and so remember-able, the bully in this movie you know "You gonna cry?", yeah that kid, he was fun. The acting from everybody was really good, even the kid actors did good, nobody did a terrible performance. This movie celebrates Christmas like mad, just like Home Alone 2. And overall this movie ended on a pretty good note towards the end.The movie is freaking amazing and a good Christmas movie, but it's not on level of oh my god this is a master peace, no it's a charming, and quirky little film with a little sprinkle of heart and joy to all out there.Merry Christmas everyone.

I LOVE this movie! I cannot get enough of it! I adore every inch of celluloid! From the Santa in the mall, to the Red Rider BB Gun, to the Soap Poisoning, the tongue-stuck-on-pole, the Bunny Suit!!! The A+ Fantasy sequence, Drink Your Ovaltine! I love and adore everything about this timeless classic. I could sit and watch it over and over for 24 full hours(thank you TV)! It is NOT Christmas without watching this movie. If you have never seen this movie, you should be ASHAMED of yourself!

If you love it or hate it, everyone should know of this by now.  A major bomb when first released, kids of the 80s such as myself found it on cable year after year and loved it.  A straight-forward plot, kid wants a bb gun for Christmas, is juiced up by a ton of memorable scenes that really don't involve the holiday, but are priceless nonetheless.  The double dog dare, the leg lamp, the bully who finally gets his, and on and on.  But of the Christmas related stuff, they throw in everything you remember or have gone through.  Or depending on your age, you still may be going through it, all that anguish over getting the gift you want.  Terrific performances abound, Gavin as the high strung father who swears like a cartoon character, Dillon as the sympathetic mother, and though billed third, Billingsley is great as Ralphie.  Even at a young age, he gave totally professional line readings and facial expressions, with the trademark scene (in my mind) the charge back up the Santa slide to ramble off a hilarious request.  Really too bad that he didn't go on to a better career.  And I may as well admit, I still get a tiny tear when that final gift is unwrapped.  The music in the scene is subtle but real touching to bring out how special the moment is for the kid.  The biggest reminder of how much of a favorite this is of mine is whenever I hear the melody to "We Wish You a Merry Christmas" I automatically think of the closing credits of this film.  Definitely required viewing at least once a year.

reviews.review_title: The Only Good Christmas Movie!!!(unless Die Hard counts)---8/10
reviews.content: It is a yearly custom for me and my brother to watch this movie together around Christmas. Even though we are not Christian. The story follows a young boy living in middle America in the late 1940's. All the kid wants is Red Ryder BB gun but everything keeps getting in his way, including his overprotective mother, his snot-nosed little brother, the town bullies, and even Santa himself. This is hilarious and probably the most real Christmas movie there is. It's A Wonderful Life sucks. Home Alone's only good thing was Joe Pesci. Jingle All The Way and The Santa Clause both suck also. A Christmas Story is exactly what the title says it is. Fuuuuuuuuuu..........dge. 8/10

This movie is literally one of the best instant classic Christmas movie to watch for the whole family. It does have comedy moments, but also has a heart true spirit of Christmas. Every story they ever told of this movie was mesmerizing and absolutely an incredible Christmas Story to tell.Every family in the real world celebrates Christmas, just like every family member would celebrate the holidays. I totally recommend watching A Christmas Story. It has heart, comedy, joy and this movie finds a holiday cheer of Christmas, just like every Christmas movie deserves. The best Christmas movie ever made!Merry Christmas everybody!!!

reviews.review_title: Good Observational Humour, But Miscasting and Pace Hold it back.
reviews.content: There are homes in America and the UK where even slight criticism of this Holiday classic would have the eggnog kicked out my hand and me being kicked out the house. The story is brilliant, a Proustian memoir from both views, the writer as a child and how he now sees Christmas and what really matters. It is a classic, the Red Ryder BB Gun could be Castle Grayskull, or a Barbie, or Megatron, Nintendo DS, iPad. The story is an ingenious one. The movie really does have heart, derived from the fact that it is based on a true story and its wry family over commercialism message is something that raises it above SPielbergian schmaltz. The film's miscasting, however, is drastic and it never really recovers from this. RalPhie, Peter Billingsley, is so automaton in this as to come across borderline autistic. In a decade where Corey Feldman, Sean Astin and other, better, child actors were out there, Billingsley's acting is such that it seems the camera ceased rolling every five minutes to give the boy a nudge... or make him do something. Billingsley doesn't even really have the abilities a child extra should have, with the kids essaying Scott Farkus and Flick blowing Billingsley out of the water. Darren McGavin is way too old to be the Old Man, ironically. Was his wife twelve when he married her at forty? Imagine Bill Murray in this role, whom they could've hired at the time for a reasonable fee, or even Rick Moranis? McGavin doesn't just seem to act angry, he looks Permanently P***ed off to even have been cast. Melinda Dillion as the mother is noteworthy and overall the casting of the family should have been built around her. There are excellent moments of observational reflection from childhood, but it is Jean Shebherd's writing that saves the movie and ties it together. It is to be commended for that.No doubt that when Zemeckis remakes this as a CGI fest, maybe the last in his motion capture Christmas trilogy, this might work, but the casting and anachronisms detract from the whole.You can all tell me to fuuudge off now.

This is one of those films that is going to be around forever. A Christmas Story is one of my favorites to watch every year. No it's not A Wonderful Life or Miracle On 34th Street... But it's not Bill Murry's Scrooged either! It's pure fun entertainment. Just a typical northern household & their everyday life around the holiday's... They end up having "just one of those days!" Sadly, one of those days turns out to be Christmas Day! This is a classic & if you have not seen it, check your local listings because some networks make it into a marathon by repeating it all day on Christmas. Happy Holiday's everyone! 1-10 (9)

A timeless classic, I've been watching since I was a child. I watch it every single year at Christmas time. My kids even love it nearly 40 years after it came out. I hope no one does a woke remake, it would ruin it.

reviews.review_title: Needs to be reintroduced to TV audiences
reviews.content: This is a classic and I watch it every year. I'm surprised that it isn't not on many top 20 Christmas film lists, it probably needs to be reintroduced to audiences. This is a warm loveable funny film about a bout growing up and one Christmas day in particular.

reviews.review_title: You'll shoot your eye out kid
reviews.content: I'm sorry but this movie is so overrated. Still wondering what the majority of society saw in it. There's like no plot and only a couple of funny jokes. It's so boring, I'm surprised that I was even able to watch the whole thing. I guess nostalgia makes it a classic but I don't understand how anyone could really think of this as great movie. This movie is ok at best, I guess I just had high expectations when many people say that it's their favorite Christmas movie. I laughed I believe 2 times. One being when the father tried putting the leg lamp back together and it broke. The other time was when Ralphie started climbing back up the slide just to get a foot to the face to slide back down.

A Christmas Story is a comedy-drama tale about a boy named Ralphie Parker who wishes to receive a BB gun for Christmas. It covers the last few days leading up to Christmas, with Ralphie trying to persuade his parents, his teacher, and Santa Claus to get him the BB gun. There are many subplots to keep things interesting, but it ultimately revolves around the family. I initially wasn't too interested in watching this movie, but when I saw it was in the IMDb top 250 I figured I'd give it a try (you know, to nick another one of the list). It won me over.Stylistically, it feels like a home video. The characters are all easy to relate to, and Ralphie brings back fond memories of childhood. The narration is an interesting touch. We see this simple, normal kid on the outside, but hear his complex inner thoughts in adult English. The daydreams are also great, especially the ones involving his teacher. The film definitely has its moments... the Farkus encounters were priceless. The comedy was mostly fresh, although I admit a few of the jokes struck me as lame or cliché. I guess it depends on personal taste. The overall message left me a little befuddled at the end. I suppose it is one of those things you need to grow up with to appreciate fully.All in all, the movie is good at what its meant to be: a Christmas film which a whole family can watch and enjoy together. It's a Wonderful Life is still the paramount film in the genre, but this is a notable alternative.

reviews.review_title: A time capsule . How Christmas was in the late 1940's
reviews.content: If you were a middle class kid growing up in the late 40's with a traditional stay at home Mom; a Dad who swore like a sailor, was a FORD man, and thought he could fix anything and had an opinion about everything - you had to like this movie. Some of the scenes seemed to be right out of my own life. Like first time my MOM overheard me say the BIG word, and actually wondered where I had heard it. Why from my old Man of course. I wonder if my Mom EVER listened to the OLD MAN?I wanted a BB gun and never got one for Christmas. Why not? Because my Mom said exactly what Ralphie's Mom said - "you'll shoot your eye out." Unfortunately, that was one time my old Man gave in to my Mom. The Christmas tree purchase - right out of my past. My Dad who was by nature a tight wad, always would loosen up when it came to the Yule tree. Of course he always thought he won the haggle. I had a younger brother just like Randy. He wouldn't eat his peas either. He would smash them up and spread them around the bottom of the plate. In the pre-TV era, there probably wasn't a kid who hadn't sent away for something advertised on the Radio. We listened to the Lone Ranger, Sgt King of the Northwest Mounted police and when Mom wasn't paying attention, listened to the detective shows.We used language like double dare, and double double dare, although to this day, I'm not certain what it all meant. I went to a school that looked a lot like Ralphie's. Back then, most of us walked to a neighborhood school, so we had fights with older boys who were bullies, and one time in a fit of blind rage I hit one of them with a lucky punch and he never bothered me again.Then there was the question that had near theological aspects. Was there really a Santa Claus? It seemed obligatory to fool our parents, and some of us fooled ourselves "just in case" it was true. After reading some of the negatives, it appears that a generation gap exists. It is probably hard for anyone who grew up in the 60's to understand what Christmas meant for our generation. Getting presents was something that happened once a year, and if you were lucky, maybe you got a birthday present. The average home in those days was about 1000 square feet and there simply wasn't room for all the "things" we now put in our two car garages and rented space. As a grandparent I have come to accept the fact that this generation thinks Christmas comes once a week. As a movie, this is something everyone can watch and enjoy. The narration of Ralphie's thoughts is terrific. Dillon and McGavin are perfect forties parents. Some of Ralphie's imagination may seem corny to the younger viewers, but before TV and video games, I think we as kids had more imagination. I know I shot many an imaginary bad guy out my bedroom window with my imaginary gun. This has become a Christmas "cult" film because it keeps its focus on how kids saw Christmas. It's not religious, its not about adults or a love story. Unlike other so called Holiday films, such as "It's a Wonderful Life to "Christmas in Connecticut" or Chevy Chase's movies. This film captures an era just as Dickens captured his era with "A Christmas Carol". I think this film represents what Christmas meant to kids like no other film ever made.

I hate, absolutely detest, 99.9% of the past, present, and, I'm sure, future Christmas films punctually inflicted on us every year by the so-called entertainment industry. Most of it is a revolting mish-mash of cutsey-utsey, cloyingly sentimental, corny, weepy mush (who wants to cry at Christmas?). And don't even start me on the Christmas "comedies"! The whole thing is enough to turn Mary and Joseph into Scrooge.Thank God for films like A Christmas Story, A Christmas Carol (1951, with Alastair Sim), and Scrooge (1971, with Albert Finney). Oh, yeah. And the Charlie Brown one. They are the ONLY Christmas films I bother to watch. Actually, I watch them every year. Heck, watching them every day is better than even reading the synopsis of the new stuff once a year.This film is funny, endearing, and REAL. There is at least ONE thing that lucky old codgers like me can identify with in this gem. No weepies, no tacky sentimentality, no dysfunctional families, no over-the-top, tiresome "comedy" (going on a trip and leaving your kid Home Alone on Christmas? Seriously?!)So a big thank you to Jean Shepherd, Bob Clark, and all the film cast for bringing back the real magic of Christmas: Christmas itself. God bless you, guys. Every one.PS: don't listen to the 1 *reviewers. They're all a bunch of Grinches who don't know a good thing when they see it. I bet they all loved E.L.F.

reviews.review_title: "And just WHAT do you want for Christmas, LITTLE BOY???!!!???"
reviews.content: Take a look at that Santa Claus scene.You just look at that Santa visit and you try, you just TRY to tell me that this isn't the best Christmas movie ever made.You can't can you?I didn't think so.Merry Christmas to all.

It's the REAL Christmas story in everyone's life!It's an upbeat, happy movie......not like a lot of the others, that bring sadness, or total ridiculous-ness.It's pure, honest and nostalgic, thank you for a movie to watch with others or alone, and still feel happy inside!

I watch this movie every Christmas season. It captures the mind of a child perfectly, is humorous, and the 1940 setting is a delight. It is a rare perfect movie. I feel bad for anyone who doesn't get it.

reviews.review_title: If you hate it, then you are a Grinchy Scrooge!
reviews.content: After reading the comments posted for this movie, a vast majority of people really love this movie.  And the majority rules!  For those that hate it, their hearts may be two sizes too small.This movie is a classic due to its ability to hold through the test of time. It captures an innocence that is no longer portrayed in family Christmas movies (some dumb cluck listed that Die Hard is a Christmas movie, showing how rednecks regard the holiday joy).  For the ones who hate it, they mostly hate it because they don't know the point of the movie, showing that they won't allow their inner child to enjoy it.  The movie stands out from other Christmas films, because it shows Christmas through the eyes of a child, rather that an adult character, a family struggle or third person.  Granted, the narrator is the child grown up, and remembering that year in his life, but he remembers his thoughts about his struggle to achieve that one present that meant more to him than anything else.  Think to when you were a child, and there was one Christmas that you wanted something more than anything else in the world, so much so that you bribed your parents, cleaned your room, wrote letters to Santa, hit up your grandparents, and any other angle that you could think of to get that gift!  If you can remember that Christmas, and what that gift was, then that is why you would love this movie, because you can identify with Ralphie, and his quest, you can remember your own childhood longings at Christmas, and that will bring you into the movie, and bring the movie into your collection.I give it a 12 out of 10! You should as well.
Cute and wholesome. I think this actually captures the magic of Christmas Day that you feel as a child.The gift opening scene was just magic. So cute.

"A Christmas Story" is one of those films that's become an annual American Christmas tradition. It plays back-to-back 24 hours every single year on Christmas Day on television. It's hard to not at least be somewhat familiar with this movie through TV commercials with extremely iconic scenes such as the leg lamp, the bunny suit, the Red Rider BB gun, "you'll shoot your eye out!", and the bar of soap.I'll say it's very funny and I especially love the Old Man, played by Darren McGavin. The eloquent narration by Jean Shepherd, dramatizing all of the little things. It's the subtle humor of this movie that I really love, the way ordinarily mundane things are suddenly transformed into some big event. Classic stuff and very funny. If you haven't seen this at some point in your life you really have no excuse because it's on TV every year for an entire day and I swear that my grandpa and my dad can both quote this movie line by line.

reviews.review_title: 9 year old Ralphie must convince his mom, teacher, and even Santa that a BB gun is the perfect Christmas Gift.
reviews.content: This is easily in my opinion the best Christmas movie ever made, along with Frank Capra's 1946 classic "It's a Wonderful Life." "A Christmas Story," embodies the true spirit of every child nearing Christmas time. The film is seen through the eyes of a 9 year old boy named Ralphie Parker. Just like most children nearing the holiday season, Ralphie shares a common obsession for a gift. But the only roadblock he faces is the fact that he wants a BB gun. This film is packed with memorable and heartwarming scenes. One unique aspect of "A Christmas Story," is that almost each and every character has their own special moment in the movie. One of the many reasons this movie is so loved and sought after is because Ralphie is such a relatable character. I admit that even I have shared a common need for "Thee," Christmas gift and I'm sure that you, yes you reading this, have had that same feeling. Weather its the old man winning his "Major Award," or even smart assed Schwartz sticking his tongue to the flagpole, "A Christmas Story," is sure to keep you laughing and is able to find a special place in everybody's heart as one of their favorite movies of all time.

I'm in my 50's and grew up with "It's a Wonderful Life" and "A Christmas Carol" as my two must-see films each Christmas. After 25+ years, "A Christmas Story" was added to my list. Have watched it annually for almost 20 years.So many great scenes; so many great lines. Fragile becomes an Italian import. Deranged Easter bunny. You'll shoot your eye out. Be sure to drink your Ovaltine. Tapestry of obscenity. F--- word. Ralphie's daydreaming. I can't get up. It is a film for those who remember that special Christmas. I think that is the Christmas when the magic of Santa and the magic of your parents converge.

reviews.review_title: Deserves to be a Christmas Classic
reviews.content: I heard about this movie from a friend, long after its theatrical release and rented it one Christmas season a few years back. This film deserves to be the Christmas classic that it is becoming. It has all the right elements, humor, tenderness, quirky characters, and a happy ending. I think that any of us can identify with the kid who only wants one thing for Christmas (in this case the BB gun), but is convinced he won't get it. There are a lot of very funny moments in this film and the family is perfectly cast. Darren McGavin is great as the dad, and I have always liked Melinda Dillon. The ending sends a message of universal understanding, but doesn't clobber you with a "message". This is a perfect Christmas movie, because the whole family can truly enjoy it.

reviews.review_title: This is how it really WAS . . .
reviews.content: This is how life really was for my brothers, my sister, and me.  The house, the clothes, the kids, the Lifebuoy soap -- I thought life was great at the time, but looking back via this picture, I realize how golden it was. This movie and Jean Shephard, whose life is depicted, deserve a place in the Christmas Hall of Fame.

I don't understand how people rate this highly as a Christmas movie? I'm watching it on tv now, not intentionally but it just started whilst I was going through channels and decided to watch. The acting is absolutely terrible. Every actor overacts. The scenes are overdone and unbelievable. I know some movies are like that but this is like if a kid wrote it and decided to "do stupid things in a scene" etc. The jokes are straight out of a playground. Not really funny at all.I don't even get a nice "Christmas feeling" from it. In the 80s they definitely had much funnier more inventive things than this so it's not a generational thing at all. I've tried to give it a chance but I'm turning off now.

Whoa, whoa hold up. I thought this movie was supposed to be good. After all the praise I've heard for this movie and it turns out to be crap? Am I the only one who didn't like this movie? I'm not crazy, there has to be someone out there who agrees with me. This movie was honestly just painful to watch. Everyone was annoying. Ralphie was annoying, his brother was annoying, his friends were annoying, and his parents were annoying. Throughout the entire film I wanted to punch Ralphie's brother right in the mouth. I didn't laugh once during the entire movie either. It just wasn't funny. If there was a funny moment, please, enlighten me. Once it was over I came to a conclusion: that the people who love this movie watched it as a kid and remember it fondly, or I'm completely insane. The latter, I think not.

OK, so this was not an Oscar-worthy film. BIG DEAL! It was great! Being 36 years old, most Christmas movies don't do it for me. Most seem to be the cookie-cutter, feel-good types. ****SOME MINOR SPOILERS FOLLOW*** BUT...with Ralphie's quest for the Real Rider, and the eternal struggles throughout the movie...this brought back some good memories, because they were struggles that many of us could relate to as kids! Bullies, Triple Dog Dares, wanting something SO badly for Christmas and trying to convince your parents of it, the Mall Santa, the cursing father, slipping out a bad word in front of your parents, the soap in the mouth...I mean, c'mon! This was great stuff! Not like the spoiled kids of the more popular Christmas movies (see "Home Alone" or "Jingle All The Way"), living in their big, luxurious houses. This was old-school Americana all the way, with the bargaining for the Christmas tree, the "Major Award" Leg Lamp, and the "Battle of The Boiler."It's edgy. It's not P.C. It's not totally "feel good." But, it's WORTH watching. By FAR, my favorite Christmas movie!

reviews.review_title: A Christmas Film unlike any other
reviews.content: A well paced plot, memorable characters, great comedy and a warm tone that perfectly captures the heart of the holidays. It is innocent, but also darkly realistic when it needs to be, so it never becomes cheesy. However the black comedy never goes far enough to become mean spirited. It manages to strike the perfect balance. Anyone of any age can enjoy this master piece that stands apart from other classics like Christmas Carol, It's a Wonderful Life, Miracle on 34th street etc

I can watch this movie over and over and never get tired of it. It has become a family tradition that I will watch year after year! The casting was excellent and to have been a low budget film it turned out very well done. There are a few family movies that I like to watch at Christmas and this is at the top of the list. I also enjoyed the 20th anniversary edition so I could see what the actors looked like now. They all still appreciate the welcome they receive from people that have watched this show for years. I like it when actors still care about the movies that made them famous. Thank you to the entire cast for making such a wonderful Christmas movie for us to enjoy.

Based on the short stories of humorist Jean Shepherd (who also narrates), a nine-year-old boy (Peter Billingsley) wants a genuine Red Ryder 200-shot Carbine Action Air Rifle for Christmas, much to the disapproval of his parents (Melinda Dillon, Darren McGavin).  Will he get his most desired present?Great performances by Billingsley and McGavin, non-stop humor and director/co-writer Bob Clark's ("Porky's") attention to detail highlights this near-perfect holiday film that deserves to be a Christmastime classic like "It's a Wonderful Life" and "Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer."  Merry Christmas.  My evaluation: ***½ out of ****.

I really love Christmas classics, especially ones with humor in it. Sure, it's nice to know about the true reason for Christmas, but it's also fun to watch movies that deal with American culture. :) The "A Christmas Story" was very funny! The last time I watched it I was around 12-14 years of age. Now I'm 17 and my perspective on the movie has changed a lot (I understood the swearing and profanity jokes, for one thing) but the love for it stayed the same.The only problem I have, as usual, is the profanity. Even though it was a major thing with the plot, it still was a bit, unnerving because it was swearing! The jokes were fine though!

Every year it's the same old Christmas. Though, it does come with some quirks. A little up, and a little down it can be during the holidays. WE all know how that is. Well, Bob Clark (Director) found Leigh Browns (Author) story `A Christmas Story' as a great example of those moments and placed them in his Holiday extravaganza. Well, the movie is about a kid Ralph 'Ralphie' Parker (Peter Billingsley), who wants a Red Ryder BB gun for Christmas. Set during the 1940's Ralphie runs into the problem that his mom thinks he will shoot his eye out. During the film it has Ralphie trying his best to succeed. Though can he do it?With this story being also a reflection of childhood, as it unfolds in first person, the flick was all right. Filming wise was a little cooky sometimes, but was decent. The acting was good, but sometimes they had to act too overdramatic. Though that does give the flick some flavor.I would say this film is only good if one is interested in a Christmas satire. I myself found moments to be good and funny, but after awhile it got dull and boring. I would say this film is OK to watch one time through. Other than that it is really tedious to sit through.

I do not absolutely hate this movie, and I have seen it a fair amount of times.  However, to me, this movie seemed very shallow and therefore missed any true Christmas atmosphere that it could have contained.It really is the motif of this film that is a turn-off to me.  I can understand that you would enjoy the film if you identify with Ralphie's childhood experiences, but from my perspective, the whole atmosphere of the film just seemed bleak and empty.  My feelings could best be summed up by saying that I thought this was a rather dark film, more dark than Christmas-y.  The parents seem shallow and are nothing more than parodies, and the brother seems to be a whimpering non-character.  Individually, the characters are funny, but the sum of the parts fails to make a whole; the characters are defined by nothing more than their comedic antics, and there is nothing more to them.  The sheer lack of realistic and meaningful interpersonal relationships in this movie makes it feel hopeless, in spite of its comedy.  Not even Santa is jolly!  Visually, although capturing some atmosphere of the era, the film just seems monochromatic.  Overall, it just seems impoverished when it comes to rich characters or visual lushness. If the film had but one or two meaningful characters or places to redeem itself, it would be far more tolerable.  I realize that this is a comedy, but the main reason that I do not like this movie is that I find the atmosphere and the taste of the humor depressing.  In fact, I don't understand why people view Ralphie's childhood as blissful and sweet, because it simply doesn't come across that way to me.  Moreoever, the idea that it is a Christmas movie is sortof incidental and gets lost in the plot; it could have easily been about a boy's birthday or any other gift-giving occasion, because other than spartan Christmas imagery and the Santa scene, there is little in the movie that is actually relevant to the holiday.
If you identify with Ralphie's childhood experiences, or appreciate the cynical, sarcastic humor, you will probably like this film, but if you agree with me, it will just leave you feeling icky.

This film was obviously made with the kids being their target viewers. But the whole film is full of bad words, profanities, ways of telling lies to parents, romanticizing air guns for kids, inappropriate sexual lamp, promotion of chinese restaurants and what not!

For at least the past 10 years I can't remember a single Christmas when my family and I didn't sit down and laugh at this film like it was the first time we'd seen it. The movie's a marvel when it comes to capturing what a child feels like during Christmas.My favorite scene is one where Ralphie finally confronts the school bully. A scene everyone who's ever been picked on by a bully will applaud.

A Christmas Story is widely known as an American holiday classic about Ralphie Parker (Peter Billingsley), a young boy who's heart is set on one sole gift for Christmas, a BB Gun. This film is easy to enjoy and provides enough laughs for a recommendation. Some parts are relatively cheesy, but that's all part of the movie's nature. A gem for such scenes as the infamous tongue~stuck~to~pole fiasco and the "leg lamp",  this movie is the definition of a family film. Darren McGavin who plays Mr. Parker, is a standout in this playful, not to be too serious, Christmas delight.VERDICT: *** of **** Recommended

The most delightful Christmas movie ever! I'm so envious of all the commentators that say they watch it with their families. Nobody in my family, including my husband, enjoys the movie as much as I do. My brother and I are the only ones who love this movie (he lives in Florida now so I have no one to share the laughter with me). I HOPE TNT runs "A Christmas Story" marathon again this year; it was so great! Think about it...if you like this movie and there wasn't anything good on the other channels you could always rely on "A Christmas Story."

reviews.review_title: How could you not love this!!!
reviews.content:
This is by far, one of my favorite movies of all time.  The networks play in year round.  It is seen in summer, spring, winter, and fall.  It is hysterical and so well done.  The producers didn't miss a beat.  Watching this movie makes me yearn for a more peaceful and sentimental time in America's history.  It was a time of joy and happiness, and family values. 
The casting could not have been any more perfect.  Billingsley was perfect as Ralphie.  Dillon and McGavin were classic.  Randy was priceless.I give it a 9.5 out of 10.  Watch it over, and over, and over!

By far, this is the greatest Christmas movie to come out since 1983. Nothing can top it (Within that time frame).  A true Delight for the whole family...Any family!  In one way or another, we can all relate to Ralphie...we have all coveted a certain gift, and begged for it for Christmas.I have already started watching this film, in preparation for Christmas...Yeah, normally I don't start till the end of Novemeber, but I can't help myself.  I LOVE THIS MOVIE!!!!And to know that the actor (Scott Schwartz) who plays FLick  in 1997 started a Porn career....how funny is that!Truly a superior film, and could not be duplicated....This is when movies were good, and not full of Hollywood BS!  "Oh, Fudge!"
11 out of 10

THIS IS A FANTASTIC MOVIE TO WATCH EVEN WHEN IT'S NOT AROUND THE HOLIDAYS!! I GOT A KICK OUT OF IT WITH THE SAYING YOU'LL SHOOT YOUR EYE OUT,AND THE WORD UNCLE!!    THE BEST PART OF THE WHOLE MOVIE WAS WHEN RALPHIE(PETER BILLINGSLEY) GETS SNOWBALLED BY SCUT FARKUS(ZACK WARD) AND GROVER DILL(YANO ANAYA).

This movie could be the Big Bang of sitcom. (I wonder if I should review it since it's banality caused me to stop watching early on.) Unceasingly irritating, in the writing, direction, acting and the camera work. Now, I truly understand that we all can't appreciate any given movie but in this case I wonder how it's possible that the people who gave it 9 or 10 stars, the majority, are living and experiencing the same life experience as I am? This movie displays fraud, fraudulence and manipulations of creative endeavor for what end? I'll answer the question: Shepherd was in his early sixties when he came up with the idea for 'A Christmas Story'. He had made a pile of money but probably wanted to secure a lot more with old age pressing him. So he does, in its way, something brilliant: An overly sentimental 'Christmas story' that has incredible satiric and contemptuous bite to it. But he disguises it as sentiment! Voila! He pulled it off. He made the squares he so held in contempt buy into this dose of Norman Rockwell gone wild. And if anyone reading this disagrees with the content of the review and wants to actually follow through on seeing if there's any truth to my comments, then do some homework and listen to his brilliant radio monologues. Shepherd was one talented angry observer and A Christmas Story is the exact opposite of what he talked about and was during hundreds of hours of broadcasting.

reviews.review_title: Wish the real year of the movie would be posted
reviews.content: This movie did not come out in the 80's. We moved at the end of the 70's and had been watching it in the late 70's. I am guessing the real release year date is 76 to 77ish.Any one have the REAL release date.As for the movie, it was great back then and it is great now. It is great to see how Christmas was and how in some ways it has gotten better. The Father was in a Creature Feature type series in the 70's which one would think would not allow him to play this Dad. I am very happy to have seen him make that transition back then to this movie. I only wish he had been in more movies.

So true to life!! Altho filmed in the 80's, this move is so reflective of life in So-Cal in the 40's - 50's. (The "War" years). I actually lived some of these scenes - hitting the neighborhood bully, sticking my tongue on a frozen street sign pole, "waiting for my Father to get home" and afraid of Santa. I was "Ralphy;s" age at the time I went through the "trauma" of the Christmas season, waiting for Santa, Mom & Dad getting us kids to bed early Christmas Eve, visiting the {Ugh} relatives.* Wal-Mart actually sold a copy of the Daisy BB rifle this year ('08) for $39. * * Copies of the infamous Leg-Lamp are available in life-size as well as night-lights complete with the fringe lampshade. *Kudos to Jean Shepard !!

I remember this movie being released back in 1983 in movie theatres and I also remember that it did not play too long in theatres and had come and gone so fast.When I watched this on cable two years later,I realized and learned why it did not play too long.This movie practically is a huge mess in itself that it is not even funny.IMHO,this movie is not even funny at all.It does not even survive on a "So Bad.It's Good!" level.It bored me to death.Instead of laughing,I was yawning throughout hoping for something to arouse my ability to chuckle.Nothing happened.Oh well! This whole movie is nothing but over 90 minutes of senseless profanity and bad acting that it does not even arouse interest.After a promising start,the whole movie rolls downhill and does not even recover.Plus,the premise of a kid wanting THE perfect gift is reduced to WORTHLESS trash as the kid does whatever it takes to get his way.What was MGM thinking when they agreed to fund and release this movie in theatres?Not only that,how could this movie receive a PG rating by the MPAA with all of the senseless profanity?This film should have received an R rating for all of that.Not only that,in some communities,some people who took their kids to see the movie actually stormed out of theatres demanding their money back after they heard all the obscenities uttered by the child actors and adult actors.None of these parents could not believe that a holiday movie dubbed as a "Family Movie" could have all of that.That is why the movie did not last very long and caused such a media storm that was unheard of for a so called "Holiday Themed Family Movie".I only watched the film on cable because it was directed by Bob(Porky's,From The Hip)Clark.I like Bob Clark.He directed two of my favorite movies of the 1980's,which are the ones described in parenthesis in between his name.My feelings for Bob Clark have not changed but this movie was the WORST movie of his career.That is why I give it two stars because I can not give one star to a Bob Clark film.He would later redeem himself with many other good films released in the years followed.But this film,it's a film that he should have thought twice about before taking the helm or even think of having a screenplay written.Overall,this is the WORST holiday movie ever made.This movie is so bad and boring that it truly belongs in the trash bin.If you want to watch a holiday comedy,watch Jingle All The Way,which is a very FUNNY movie that never goes stale with every viewing.This movie should have "Avoid At All Costs" written all over it because that's how bad it really is.Avoid it if you have not seen it.

reviews.review_title: A must see in our Christmas season.
reviews.content: Although TBS has ran this movie in the ground, its still a movie me and my family watch once a year for Christmas. I was one of a lucky few to have seen this movie in the theaters but by the time I tried to tell my friends (I happened to be the same age as Ralphie when it came out) it was out of theaters. If you haven't seen it by now you probably wont appreciate it as much due to all the hype its received in the past 15 years. Also, judging from the negative reviews (couldnt believe there were any) if you an anti-gun nut or you like the movie Its a wonderful Life, you will hate this movie. So basically, if you more than 100 years old, don't bother!

"A Christmas Story" is my most favorite Christmas movie ever.  The story is wonderful, the characters truly believable, and the attention to detail in sets and costumes is amazing.  Even though it's set about 20 years before my time, I remember having Christmases like that as a child!  I remember the anticipation, the sucking up just this short of outright begging, and the day of days itself arriving and waking up to a new snowfall which arrived Just In Time.  I remember the real tree, the yards of lights practically shorting out the electrical system in the house, watching the snow fall while the radio plays, the bales of fake icicles that had to be swept up.  I also remember being a kid again; single file lines to everywhere, waiting for recess or (longer still) the final bell to go home, and, unfortunately, being mercilessly tortured by a bully until I snapped and pounded the tar out him.  I even enjoyed it the one time I saw it in the middle of July!  Fa ra ra ra ra, ra ra ra ra!  (By the way, being from northern Indiana, even though it was filmed in Cleveland, "A Christmas Story" looks like it's in northern Indiana!)

Finally finished watching this film. Had to hit pause so many times. How it got its cult status is beyond me. I didn't find it funny or charming or clever. Quite the opposite, actually. It was already bad, and then to make it a hundred times worse, there was the extremely racist scene at the restaurant. Way to finish with a fart.

Many people think this is the ultimate Christmas Movie. It's not a good Christmas movie. It's not a good movie at all. When I was growing up my buddy introduced it to me. We watched this movie that he loved so much and after it finished I was left feeling a little disappointed and confused. I thought it was just ok. What was I missing? What did he see in it that I did not? As I grew older I learned that this movie is beloved by nearly everyone!So I re-watched it as an adult (36 now) and I still didn't get it. I couldn't even finish it. It is just not a good movie. Ralphie sucks as does his family. It's so weird when he just stares off into nothingness with his mouth open dreaming about his red ryder bb-gun. It was boring and not funny. The near universal praise of this movie will always be a great mystery to me.

reviews.review_title: Holds up to repeated viewings (it'd better!)
reviews.content: This movie is seriously in danger of falling to the same fate as befell "It's a Wonderful Life".  In that case, a really good movie was overplayed until everyone grew sick of it.  Too bad.That aside, this is a thoroughly enjoyable movie.  Peter Billingsley (best known before this movie as Messy Marvin from those old chocolate syrup commercials) is precocious as Ralphie, and Melinda Dillon is good as Ralphie's mother.  But the real genius was the casting of Darren McGavin (a hero of mine since "Kolchak: the Night Stalker") as the old man.  About 60 years old at the time this movie was made, he was a little old to be playing the father of young children.  Still, to a kid Ralphie's age, a 40-year old man might seem as old as 60.  An inspired choice.BY the way, the screen play for this movie was based on several chapters in Jean Shepherd's "In God We Trust - All Others Pay Cash", which I also recommend very highly.
An absolute Christmas Classic. It's funny, sweet, and full of nostalgia for childhood. A must watch every Christmas Season. I have to watch it every December 24.

reviews.review_title: This Story is good, only if you like stupid stuff, which I don't.
reviews.content: The Story is about a young man named Ralphie Parker, who wants a Red Rider BB gun for Christmas. His mom, his teacher, and Santa all agree he shouldn't get one, because "you'll shoot your eye out!" That's the main story.The Story has too many subplots. The subplots are so "sub" that they have nothing to do with the main story. Some of them last only one scene; others last several scenes. These subplots include his parents' feud with each other over a lamp shaped like a leg, Ralphie and his friends at the frozen pole, Ralphie having a swearing problem, Ralphie and his friends fighting with Scut Farkus, and others. Some of these subplots have a certain element that connect them a little bit, but the Story overall really took no talent to make it.Whoever-it-was that wrote this Story is not talented. The Story overall is *spoiler* Ralphie wants a BB gun, and he gets it at the end. What 8-year-old has written something almost just like that? Whoever-it-was that directed this Story is not talented. He didn't do anything to make the above Whoever-it-was' writing better than it was.Is this a classic movie? Maybe. But how did it become classic? I just don't know. It's not very big budget, it didn't make very much in earnings, and the humor is very minimal. Maybe the humor is a lot if you don't care about cleverness. All of the humor is stupid humor. You don't have to be smart to come up with it. I don't know much about all of you, but I laughed very little in the movie.On the positive side, I do like that it is quotable (although the only quotable lines are "You'll shoot your eye out" and "You're starving people in China"), I like the part where Ralphie is imagining shooting bad guys coming to invade his house (a little), and the part where Chinese guys are singing "Fa-ra-ra-ra-ra-ra-ra-ra-ra" (although this was not as good as I thought it was).I give it 3/10, and that's being generous.
