reviews.review_title: I found it! I found it at last!
reviews.content: I saw this movie once back in the UK, and I've never forgotten it.  The problem was, I didn't have the TV listings mag, and I missed the start, so I didn't know what I was watching (BBC transmission - no commercials).  I laughed all the way through this - the story is brilliant.  Special moments for me include the unveiling of the lamp, the visit to Santa and the little brother running along to school with his arms at 90 degrees to his body ("Mom - I can't put my arms down!").  According to some other comments, this has become a holiday staple in the US.  Unfortunately the same is not true of other countries in the world.  Citizens of the world unite - demand annual showings of this movie from your local TV station!  You have nothing to lose but yet another screening of some putrid version of "A Christmas Carol".

reviews.review_title: A classic, but one little issue bothers me
reviews.content: No contest that this is one of the all-time greatest movies of the Christmas season. And the attention to period details is wonderful. But why is Mrs. Parker's hair such a mess? Circa 1940, when the story takes place, women didn't wear their hair in a frizzy mess. Rolls were very popular, or smooth, wavy, shoulder length pageboys. It seems like a significant detail to overlook, when everything else is so period-perfect. Ralphie's teacher sports a more typical style. Mrs. Parker looks like she got a cheap home perm, and then stuck two barettes in it. In any case, it's a movie we look forward to every year.

reviews.review_title: One of the most complete, dare I say perfect movies ever made.
reviews.content: There are powers at work behind the scenes of A Christmas Story.Indeed the Shepherd/Clark Christmas work sets itself apart from other seminal holiday tales because of its contemporary and timeless holiday themes, without the overblown moral drama or the sappy renderings of childhood innocence and nostalgia. The screenplay, based on the work of humorist Jean Shepherd is totally believable in its depiction of mundane middle-class Midwestern life. The father figure for example, (portrayed brilliantly by Darren McGavin) patriarch of the Parker family, is larger than life in young Ralphies eyes, yet bumbling and simple all at the same time. The story purposely dates itself in terms of setting, which only helps to strengthen the nostalgic Americana time-long-past feel of the picture. Make no mistake the phenomenon in the re-playability factor of this film is in part because of the dysfunctional Christmas Story for which many of us can all relate, but there is a real human spirit in the story, a quest for the seemingly unattainable, and a sense that many of the trials of which we endure and cherish as people, are the greatest stories of our lives.

reviews.review_title: The Search for the Best Movie Ever
reviews.content: For those who don't know I am on a journey to find the best movie ever. I have selected 50 movies that have been considered the best movies ever through the help of Wikipedia. Throughout those series of movies you will find my reviews as I try and find a movie that is truly worthy of the title of the best movie. Once I have completed this journey which should take about a year to complete I will post my findings in a list. Well, it is Christmas time and what better way to start off the list of the best movies ever than some ye ole fashion Christmas movies. Christmas time is a wonderful time of the year and has to be one of my favorites. The cheer, the season, the friends and family, the gifts, and of course everyones' favorite: the music. However this is not a review of the Christmas Season, but of the movie A Christmas Story. You all know the one. The one that plays one repeat on TV during the whole day of Christmas and you know right there might actually be its problem. Oversaturation! This movie has been scene a million billion jillion zillion times and will be seen that many times more, but maybe there is a reason for that. It is a classic. It is nostalgic. It what Christmas tradition means. It has the visit to Santa. That one gift you wanted for Christmas when you were a kid more than anything else in your entire life. Christmas tradition is what this movie is all about and that is okay and that is what makes it memorable in our hearts. We can all in some way relate to the movie if we look for it.Now this movie is not without its flaws, not only is it over-saturated, but it is not really with the times. Your parents might say that that is what Christmas was like when they were young, but it has been many years and with that time there has been more change than ever before. We have made advances in technology in leaps and bounds making for a different Christmas experience than one portrayed in the movie. In the end this movie is all about tradition and if this movie is part of your Christmas tradition than continue to have yourself a Merry Christmas.Flaws: Oversaturation and not really up with the timesStrengths: It is a classic, it is traditional, and fills you with timeless laughs

reviews.review_title: Beyond a doubt, THE classic Christmas tale!
reviews.content: This movie is just a fantastic piece of cinema.  I first saw this movie in the theatre with my family...of the four of us, my father was the only one not rolling on the floor. Ralphie is one of the greatest characters ever scripted.  He IS the movie, although the father and little brother both share some of the more humorous scenes (the furnace, lamp, and meatloaf scenes). This movie IS Christmas at our house...the tree doesn't go up until after the first viewing.  A Christmas Story isn't watched in our house as much as it used to...ONLY because my brother and I have since aged and left the nest.  Although, these past few years have been great, thanks to TNT's 24 hour--12 run marathon. Of which, I am around to watch with my mother, while my dad sounds awfully like the father character, grumbling, "How can ANYONE watch that movie more than once in a row?" Very easily, when it is one as highly entertaining as this one. Great story and great acting!  You CAN'T help but smile when thinking about this movie!
This used to be my favorite Christmas movie but over the years it's just really lost its appeal. The old man has always been the best part. Especially when he's off camera fighting the furnace.

I can honestly say I did not like this movie. Some people enjoy some comedy, and fa Ra Ra Ra Ra was hilarious, but other than that it was infantile and in no way worth 2 hours. The whole thing was a repetition of "you'll shoot your eye out" and it was slow paced and dumb. The Dad had some funny parts and the kid was kinda cute, but it was extremely annoying and ended so expected. It was a cliché Christmas movie with no climax, no entertaining plot, and it was obsessed over some 12-inche triple rifle BB gun s**t. DON'T watch this move, it is NOT a classic and it is no way better than most Christmas movies I watched. Watch It's a Wonderful Life, and if you are sick of it, just watch it again. It would still be better than this movie.In all this movie made me want to "shoot my eye out"

reviews.review_title: A Worthy Addition to the Christmas Collection
reviews.content: It's hard to believe that a movie made in 1983 could cement itself in the stable of holiday must-see films, yet since the first time I saw it, it's been on my list to watch between Thanksgiving and New Year.  It doesn't have the warm holiday glow or old-fashioned nostalgia of Wonderful Life or White Christmas, but that's not necessarily a bad thing; this film occupies a category almost by itself.There are some who have expressed a distaste for the film, and I imagine it's for many of the same reasons that some didn't care for The Grinch in 2001.  If you watch this film thinking it's about Christmas, or about a BB gun, or to be funny in the traditional sense, you will probably come away disappointed.  However, if you just sit back and take in what is given to you, it is almost certain to draw you in with its charm.The basic premise of the story is that Ralphie (Peter Billingsley) is on a quest to get a prized BB gun for Christmas.  The true shine of this film is in the details that surround it.  The story is narrated by an adult Ralph (voiced by Jean Shepherd, who also wrote the book whereupon it's based, In God We Trust, All Others Pay Cash), likely a brainchild for the Wonder Years format.  And he tells it in fine form, giving the events of an 8-year-old boy the visage of an epic story, which to a boy that age, things like BB guns and bullies and radio programs (50 years ago) were indeed the foundation of the world.Adding to this winning formula, hilarious yet common occurrences pepper this film with humor: boys flash-freezing their tongues to flagpoles, having one's mouth washed out with soap, sending in vouchers for secret decoder pins, the overactive imagination of a child, the taboo of dirty language, hideous clothing your aunt made for you... each with their own punch line which I dare not spoil here.What makes this everyday brand of humor hilarious are convincing performances by Billingsley, Ralphie's mother (Melinda Dillon) and father (Darren McGavin), the idyllic Midwestern setting, the nostalgia of the 40s that perhaps has drawn in older audiences more than younger... it just FEELS like a typical American family.  Relating to these characters is critical to making the subtleties of this film effective, and I think it is pulled off splendidly.Today's moviegoers may prefer The Grinch or Christmas Vacation for yuletide humor, and both are fine films in their regard, but I find myself without fail laughing harder at this quiet surprise than either of those.

Everytime this movie comes on, I change the channel. Why, I find this movie to be nothing by lightweight fluff. When I want a  heartwarming Christmas Movie, I put in my copy of Scrooge with Alister Sim. And the last reason, because I did not get my BB gun for Christmas! Always one excuse after another, including, "Your put your eye out!"

reviews.review_title: Only fun to watch on Christmas time!
reviews.content: Yeah it may look stupid and goofy to watch when it's not Christmas but this annoying movie airs 24 hours on Christmas Eve and Day on TBS and TNT every year on Christmas. It's entertaining to watch when your with the family.

It always amazes me when I hear someone say they have never seen this movie... If you are one of the few that have not, do yourself a huge favor, run out and buy it! Watch it once, and it will be one of your favorite movies for the rest of your life. Pure innocence and joy in an age past that engulfs the Christmas spirit, and reminds everyone of hear-filled memories. Peter Billingsly's finest film ever, and the rest of the cast are simply brilliant........ ............ ........... ... ........... ............... .................. ............ ............. ............. .............. ............ ............ ............. ............ .................. ......... ............. ........ ...... ....... ....... .......... ...........

I never tire of seeing this movie.  It's so true to life and it's not so sentimental like other Christmas movies.  I love the older Ralphie's observations, they provide so much laughter and insight.Kudos to TNT for running it for 24 hours!  It's funny each time.
How is this considered a classic? It is easily one of the dumbest movies I've ever seen...even if it was meant to be a stupid movie, it failed at that.

reviews.review_title: Simple comments regarding movie and performances.
reviews.content: This movie is not only a fine family Christmas classic, but it is also a hilarious comedy.  All of the performances are perfect, but McGavin as "The Old Man" steals the show.  It is one of those rare films that can never be seen too often.

this movie is one of my all-time favorite Christmas movies.  I first saw it when I was a kid and I haven't stopped liking it since.  it's on my top list of great films.  spectacular piece of work.  can't wait to sit down and watch it again...and again and again.

This is my most favorite movie of all time. every time it is on TV I always watch it, especially during Christmas time, because that is my favorite time of year. I love this movie so much that I watched one tape so much that it would not work anymore and had to get another one. This one will probably wear out also. I would recommend this movie to anyone, even though the leg lamp is in there, which i believe is alright if little kids see it. When I first saw this movie I didn't really get it. I first watched it when I was little around three or so. Ever since then I fell in love with it and will never turn down watching it. Most people I talk to don't like it or haven't seen it, I don't know were they have been to not seen it but the people who have not liking it. I think they need their head examined. It is my favorite movie and no one is telling me any different!!

reviews.review_title: This movie will capture the Christmas spirit in everyone!
reviews.content: A Christmas Story is played over and over in our house at Christmas Time. We must watch it twenty-five times each year. To anyone who loves Christmas and remembers each year so fondly, especially as a child, this movie is guaranteed to add to your holiday nostalgia. There is a Ralph Parker in all of us. He represents the spirit of Christmas with the innocence, magic and genuine nature that children have, especially around the holiday season. So watch A Christmas Story this year and it will warm your heart.
Just came across this movie on sky so decided to watch it and seriously where has this movie been all my life. Pure classic a must watch. Kids could enjoy it but also double entendres for the adults.

reviews.review_title: Excellent family movie for adults and children alike
reviews.content: Our family watches this movie every year at Christmas time at least once or twice. We know just about every line by heart. We even bought our son a Red Ryder BB gun for Christmas last year even though I was afraid he might "Shoot his eye out!" The movie reminds adults of their childhood with each scene and entertains children of all ages. Peter Billingsly does a fantastic job at the age of 12 playing a nine-year-old "Ralphie". His fierceness of trying to get his treasured present and his acting was amazing when fights back against the childhood bully, Fargus. Darren McGavin is hysterical as the father obsessed with the furnace and fighting with the neighbor's dogs. This movie is a classic that everyone should see once. Because after the first time, they will want to see it again and again and again.

This is definitely a favorite movie of mine. It is a holiday tradition that I watch every year. No matter how many times I have seen "A Christmas Story", I laugh just as much. It really puts me in the holiday spirit. All of the characters in this movie are excellent in their roles. The children are wonderful and any child can relate to some of the things Ralpie goes through at both school and at home. I like that this movie is suitable for all ages and does not focus on any of the commercialism we often see in today's holiday movies. I think anyone who watches this movie would agree that it is a Christmas movie classic and will remain so for generations to come.

My words alone cannot describe how brilliant this film is-for a Christmas movie anyway. I can totally relate to this despite the fact I'm only 15. It's one of my favorite Christmas films of all time! Hell, I even make my family and friends watch it every year around Christmas time to get in the mood (I've turned it into a tradition). Ralphie's the cutest thing I've ever laid eyes on. I empathize every bit of embarrassment he's been through during the movie SPOILER: (ex. When everyone thought he was going to shoot his eye out and they were right, at least they never knew that-heh heh, or when his father caught him blurting the F dash dash dash word). Jean Shepard sure had some Christmas. All in all, the movie's cool, I recommend it to anybody...

reviews.review_title: One of the most humorous movies, ever!
reviews.content: This film is meant to be watched over and over, like a fine wine, it only gets better with age.Poor Ralphie is tormented by bullies, crazy dogs next door, and the dream of a Red Ryder BB gun for Christmas.This is the story of Ralphie, his father - a man who used vulgarity the way a lesser artist might use marble, of his friends who experience the dangers of pole-licking on cold winter's days, of the piquant taste of Lifebuoy soap for mouth washing, of secret decoder rings and a Leg Lamp.Rent it, Buy it, Enjoy it.9 out of 10. Only the very best get a 10.

reviews.review_title: why do people love this film so much?
reviews.content: After seeing it on TNT on Xmas day, all day.  I came to the conclusion that this movie is the most overrated piece of garbage that exists in film history.  Why is this film loved by all? a weak story, unbelievable characters and annoying fantasy scenes.  You want to watch a good Christmas film watch Scrooged or National Lampoon's Xmas vacation.  Avoid this awful film, pure crap.

I happened by the place where they shot the flat tire scene. It was late one night in Toronto, down by the lake on Cherry Street. I remember wondering what such an old car was doing parked on the side of the road just below the old iron bridge. I never saw any of the characters and I wasn't looking for any. But I remember thinking "this must be a movie shoot" because of the trailers parked off the road. Later when I saw the the car and the bridge in the movie I knew it had to be what I saw that night. Everything in that movie was so "right on" to the time. Even the two bully's in the alley. Very funny. The brother all wrapped up in the snowsuit was priceless. My younger brother had to go through exactly the same thing every morning.

reviews.review_title: One of the best Christmas movies ever.
reviews.content: Many say that Christmas is for kids, which is true.  But at Christmas time we all become kids again.  "A Christmas Story" is the best Christmas movie that focuses on the holiday from a kids point of view.  What I really like about this movie are the performances of all the kids, not only the main characters.  They're all just great.

After reading some of the comments that are posted about this movie I am puzzled.  I don't know anybody can't enjoy watching this movie.  Maybe the people that are writing bad reviews are either too cynical or too old to enjoy it. However, with that said, I must say that I think that this movie is perfect for all ages.  There is a character inside us all which we can relate to any one of the characters in this movie.  A Christmas Story is played all the time on TNT during the holiday season.  There is a reason that this is done and a reason that this movie has lasted for about 20 years.  We all know that all holiday get-togethers do not go perfectly and this movie shows the true pleasures of the Christmas season.  If you haven't seen this movie I strongly recommend it.

This is THE Christmas movie that I absolutely have to watch every Christmas. I remember the first time I saw the movie; I loved it then and still do. I just have this great feeling every time I see The Old Man yell at the Bumpuses or I see Ralph say "Oh, Fudge" This is truly a classic, and I haven't missed a Christmas Eve without seeing it yet (although the tape is quite worn out).

I have always loved this movie,but I have one problem,someone in here said it is set in post world war chicago. If you know anything of this film you would knowit`s set in Cleveland,Ohio and was even filmed there. they even mention the old Halle`s building in Downtown Cleveland and even filmed the store santa scene there.

This is without a doubt my favorite Christmas movie of all time. I love everything about it. I never got that BB gun when I was a kid, so I felt Ralphie's pain. Personally, I think that he got of lightly with the Lifeboy soap in the mouth. My mom always used liquid Palmolive. Do you have any idea how hard that stuff is to rinse out?? It keeps foaming up on you when you try to rinse!The late great Darren McGavin's the best. The look of pride after he sends his oldest son to sit in the car after he utters "fudge". His cursing at the boiler and stammering with fury at the shattering of his major award was the absolute best...."Nada Finga!!!"

This movie is the ultimate Christmas movie ever! I firmly recommend this movie to EVERYONE! If you haven't seen this movie, you should see it, now! I love the way that it truly shows what is going on in a child's mind at Christmas time. The acting is awesome, the cast is awesome, and they all make the movie the most entertaining I have ever seen. I really like it that tbs plays 24 hours of "A Christmas Story" from Christmas Eve to Christmas Night. To be completely honest with you, I have NEVER seen a better movie, ever! I cannot recommend this movie enough, it is better than "Star Wars." In conclusion, I think that everyone should have a Red Ryder BB gun, they are very good for Christmas. Those are the great words of Master Ralphie Parker.

reviews.review_title: Probably the best Christmas Movie ever - Really!
reviews.content: I first saw this movie when it originally played in the movie theaters, and laughed so hard I thought I was going to pee myself!  Ever since that time, I've watched it every year.  I now appreciate some of the more subtle, poignant parts of the movie, and go from laughing out loud, to having a few sentimental tears come to my eyes.  To view this movie is to see Christmas through the eyes of a child.  This year (1998) I watched the movie 5 or 6 times, and enjoyed it every time.ps .. I've been told by several family members that I was a "dead ringer" for Ralphie when I was his age!

this movie is incredible i could watch it 24 hours a day.I always watch the 24 hour marathon every Christmas into Christmas day.This movie is so funny and cheerful i just absolutely love it.i could live of this movie and never watch anything else again.I have watched this movie ever since i was a kid.I always look if its playing on t.v.This movie should be a historic landmark of Cleveland.I live in Cleveland.I want to visit the museum every day.I LOVE this movie.I charish it.I love and know every comment in the movie.I know every thing to know about this movie.I think they all the characters had all the right parts in this movie

reviews.review_title: The best of the Christmas movies
reviews.content: What a great and funny movie; each year a laugh at it.  Most Xmas movies try to create a picture of this single wonderful day on which all of the not so good things about the world are suspended while we gather around the fire and talk about peace on earth.  Christmas Story, on the other hand, portrays Xmas as part of the continuum of childhood, with all of the attendant psychological horrors of the rest of the year.  Full of aspirations and desires and expectations maybe, but the bullies don't get nice on Christmas and you don't always get what you want.  The look and feel of the pre-yuppie Indiana with its torn screens, uneven hedges and cracked walkways reminds me of my grandmother's neighborhood.  And Santa -  same reaction as my daughter when she first saw Santa and reacted as though this guy was a molester.  I love this movie.

Without being overly sentimental, this movie is so sweet and funny. The narrator (Peter Billingsly character as a grown up) makes the movie. His dry observations are priceless. Aside from this year's "Bad Santa" starring Billy Bob Thornton, this is my favorite Christmas movie. I could watch it every year and never tire of it. The cast is wonderful, the script perfect. What else could you want?

reviews.review_title: It was fun to be a part of this film, literally!
reviews.content: I may be a little swayed on this movie because it was filmed at my elementary school (Victoria) but none the less, it is a great 'flick'! We were able to meet the stars and be in scenes that would come to our very own t.v sets every Christmas! What a terrific experience. Since it has been 18 years since it was filmed and I have grown up and apart from everyone in my school it is fun to see them once again, as we were, every year at Christmas time. You know, you would think after seeing that movie you would know NOT to stick your tongue to the flag pole, but every boy in my school had to try it. Ester Jane, (the girl who told the teacher to look out the window at the flag pole) where are you? Excellent memories!

reviews.review_title: What a great time to have been young
reviews.content: Any one who finds fault with this movie is unbelievable. I am sure any one with negative comments never grew up in the late forties or early fifties.I remember the snow suits, the long underwear my mother insisted I wear and indeed the local bully, who eventually got his comeuppance   and there after avoided trouble. And who out there who ever grew up on the Canadian Prairies or Northern states in America have not once stuck there tongue on a metal object in the middle of January. The movie is very believable and takes the viewer back to happier times, I can still smell Lifeboy soap,my Aunts bathroom smelled of it, what a wonderful time to have lived.

My parents (boomers) showed this movie to me (millennial) when I was a kid and yes, the tropes and constructs are totally dated, that's part of the catch. This movie is supposed to be a throw back to 1940's American culture, especially during the holidays, seen through a young kids perspective. If you want and action packed ride filled with quick instant gratification, this isn't that film. Ralphie's dad is a mess, the mom is clearly a domesticated constructs of the at-home-wife, and the boys represents classic problematic 'tis the season childhood longings, bullying, and shenanigans. The movie also highlights the beginnings of consumerist culture of worthless items; the family gathers to the opening of something grand...a stocking covered leg lamp on heels that the dad won, with neighbors stopping to gawk at the site of the glowing leg. Without the narration, this movie alone would drag through and I think this is a holiday classic.

reviews.review_title: A Christmas STORY for all ages!
reviews.content: It's just not Christmas till you watch "A Christmas Story" each and every year!For those of us with just a BIT of maturity, our memories will be roused, our hearts touched, our tickle-bones tickled!Young adults and children alike will relate to each "yearning" moment Ralphie does while awaiting Christmas Day and his dream of the PERFECT Christmas gift!We who have survived those who "bully," will ADORE this story!From start to finish, all ages will be able to relate to the Father, Mother,School Teacher, Children, all engrossed in their efforts to create just the PERFECT Christmas for the rest. Treat yourself to one AWESOME, HILARIOUS, yet totally LOVING holiday tale in "A Christmas Story!"

reviews.review_title: The best! of all the Christmas fare.
reviews.content: Somehow I had manage to miss this one until I happened upon it a few years ago while flipping the channels one bored Saturday afternoon, and came in right at the tongue-stuck-to-the-light-pole scene. I was immediately captivated and charmed by this sweet, funny, nostalgic movie. I've probably seen it ten times since, and every time it makes me laugh.. The casting is perfect with Darren McGavin as the crotchety but lovable father, Melinda Dillon as the beautiful, fun-loving, and long-suffering mother, and Peter Billingsley as Ralphie. Billingsley is  every 9-year old American Boy, with his overactive imagination and dreams of  a  Red Ryder BB gun. This film has many funny moments, and some poignant ones too. But what makes this film work is its authenticity. Whether its Ralphie imagining himself going blind from "soap poisoning," his little brother's terror of sitting on Santa's lap, or  the scene where he confronts the schoolyard bullies, every  scene rings true. The narration by the story's writer, Jean Shepherd, is an added bonus. It's a gem! P.S.  To all you Grinches who hated this movie, why don't you go and watch another Tarrantino flick. It's more up your alley.

reviews.review_title: One of the top 3 Christmas movies of all time
reviews.content: This movie will always have a place in my heart. I went to see this movie at the theatre in 1983. I was 9 years old, just like "Ralphie" is supposed to be in the film. After the movie came out onto TV a couple years later, I videotaped it and watched it religiously. I watched it throughout the year, not only at Christmas time. Needless to say, I now have it in DVD format. I have literally grown up with this movie. I recommend this for an "old fashioned - family Christmas". IF you have not seen it yet, what are you waiting for? I was saddened to find out, just as I was writing this, that Darren Mcgavin just passed away. Thankfully, he will always be remembered as the "old man".He will live forever as the "old man".Peter Billingsley can be seen as the head elf in the beginning of the movie "Elf". He was uncredited in the role.The characters will stick with you all through the year. Highly recommended. Other Christmas favorites are any version of "A Christmas Carol" and of course Clark Grizwold in "National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation".

I have seen this movie at least 10 times every holiday season since my grandfather instituted the Thanksgiving tradition of watching this movie after dinner 13 years ago. It simply never gets old and the impenetrable web of BB Gun mania instantly gets me in the Christmas mood.Most people have already said most of what makes this movie great, the instant identification with the characters regardless of generation. In fact I beat up the neighborhood bully on a snowy day in a manner eerily similar to the Scott Farkus affair. And Ralphie waking up on Christmas morning is exactly as it happened in my household, not the wide awake `oh golly look what Santa brought us.' but the slow waking up and the realization that it was Christmas a few minutes later. But the greatest aspect of this movie is that it never bogs down in sentimental sweetness towards the end. I remember seeing Home Alone when I was much younger and while I liked the initial scenes of Kevin's mayhem the whole family thing bored me. The same problem occurred with Elf. Not here, it remains hilarious throughout while still retaining its realism. Throughout it all Ralphie's old man remains the foul mouthed furnace fighter, he doesn't suddenly become a saint he simply gets Ralphie a BB gun. Ralphie doesn't learn a lesson in charity or Christmas magic, he nearly kills himself and then lies to his parents like so many kids have done with their favorite dangerous toys. And because of this when Ralphie finally gets his Red Rider BB Gun it's almost like I'm getting the gift, that moment is probably the only time a movie has brought me to tears of joy.Watching this movie makes me wish egg nog was in stores year round.

Delight to watch.  Very true to life.  Great casting and direction.  Never tire of watching it every Christmas.

This movie is definitely a classic at Christmastime.  Everyone in my family insists on seeing it at least once every year, and I know I'm not in the mood for Christmas until I see it.  It's fun to watch, and it never grows old.

reviews.review_title: How the heck can you shoot your eye out?
reviews.content: Funny as heck. Although I missed out on the 50's (and 60's and 70's for that matter), it preaches truths that cross generations. reviews.review_title: The Glow of Electric Sex in the Window
reviews.content: This is easily the single movie I've seen more often than any other ("Wonderful Life" is close though). One of the funniest, most nostalgic and most durable films I can think of. Get in the Holiday spirit, dim the lights, get some egg nog or hot chocolate, wrap up under a blanket on the sofa and watch this movie.I triple-dog dare ya!

reviews.review_title: A wonderful Christmas movie we watch every year. We lived it!
reviews.content: We watch the movie A Christmas Story every year and always notice new details we missed the year before.  As a person that grew up in the same town Jean Shepherd did,(Ralphie in the movie), Hammond, Indiana, I can tell you every detail in the movie is true to the location and era which it depicts. I am a little younger than Jean but call still recall vividly a lot of the images brought forth in the movie. I became so caught up  with the movie and the book from which it comes I began researching actual locations at the Hammond library. Jean lived in the 2900 block of Cleveland Street not far from where I grew up as a child in the 6400 block of Monroe Street in Hammond.  The house is still there but looks a little different than the one depicted in the movie.  For you book readers, Flicks Bar is actually near Jean's house and is located on Kennedy Avenue just south of the Indiana Harbor Belt Railroad overpass.  Goldblatt's Department Store was in downtown Hammond where the Santa scene takes place and was torn down several years ago.  I have a brick from the building in my basement.  It is strange but there is a family not far from where Jean's house is located that displays one of Hammond's finest outside Christmas displays called Peteyville.  Much of the display brings back the joy of Christmas's of that era.  Another strange fact, we have friends at our church that bought the house that Jean's brother, Randy, lived in for a period of time.  Harding School is about 4 blocks to the east of Jean's house and has a flag pole in front. He simply walked east on Cleveland street which dead ends at the school playground.  It looks almost exactly like the school in the film although it is was not filmed in Hammond, Indiana.  They went to great lengths to find very similar matches.  The movie is a true classic and a must see for anyone who grew up in northwest Indiana in the 40's or 50's.  It truly represents the golden days of our childhood, a time that will never be lost thanks to Jean's witty and heartfelt story.

reviews.review_title: A CHRISTMAS TRADITION FOR OUR FAMILY
reviews.content: This is THE best X-mas movie of all time. It's hillarious. It's touching. It's an X-mas family tradition. Ralphie's great. And I love "THE OLD MAN", and his sexy lamp he won from a newspaper contest. The funniest scene is where Scwarts "triple dog dares" Flik by sticking his tongue next to a frozen flagpole. And sure enough he does it. But what's funny about is the way Flik screams. He screams as if he were a woman fixing to get murdered by a crazed-psycho with an axe. Anyway, I reccomend this movie to everyone who enjoys movies.

reviews.review_title: What makes this Christmas classic work is the writing by Jean Shepherd.
reviews.content: What makes this Christmas classic work is the writing by Jean Shepherd, who also does the narration. He tried out all the stories on his improvisational radio show on WOR, New York, before working them into the novel on which the film is based. When he was doing the radio show, "Flick Lives!" signs appeared on New York walls and subways. Unlike most Christmas fare, the nostalgia has a satirical edge to it that keeps it from being too sweet. The performance by Melinda Dillon as the mom seems dead on to me, as does Darren McGavin's work as the dad. Classic moments include the tongue stuck to the flagpole and sad fate of the glowing-leg lamp. And of course we all know that if you get a BB gun for Christmas, you will indeed shoot your eye out.

reviews.review_title: this is the greatest christmas movie of all time!
reviews.content: i mean can you really put together a more timeless and wonderful movie that encompasses everything it is to be a kid, have crazy parents (like we all do), and to capture the meaning of christmas all in the same movie and make you laugh...i think not. this one is a gem of a movie.

reviews.review_title: It's just not Christmas without this movie!
reviews.content: The greatest Christmas comedy ever! This movie never ceases to make me laugh and I've seen it so much I can quote every line. The characters are fabulous. The story relatable beyond the film's 1940s timeline. It's pure fun!You can have your Wonderful Life, enjoy your Miracle on 34th Street...me? I want an official Red Ryder carbine-action two-hundred-shot range model air rifle with a compass in the stock and this thing which tells time!

A christmas story is the best christmas movie ever. Every year when christmas comes im always looking forward to the 24 hour marathon of it. The movie is about Ralphie who wants a red rider BB gun for christmas. His parents, teacher, and even the man himself Santa Claus does not agree he should have it and that its too dangerous. Ralphie will try everything he can to get the BB gun for christmas. He also runs into many problems throughout the movie, including a confrontation with Scut Farcus.

This is a wonderful, little movie.  Without any preachiness, it getsacross one message of Christmas, which is that God is in controland good things will happen.  In this case, you will get what youwant even if all of your scheming and plans go completely wrong. Peter Billingsly's insincere face is so dopey that you feel as ifBillingsly, even at that age, must have known it was a putup job. Darren McGavin is compulsively watchable in anything he does. His ability to kvetch must rank with Jimmy Stewart.  As for MelindaDillon, she's perfect because she does everything in this movie indeadly earnest.  She knows that comedy is best when donecompletely straight.  But I think the greatest praise must go to JeanShepherd.  Not only did he get most of his own material into thescreenplay, but his material is good.  This is the only Christmasmovie I know of (and possibly the only movie period) where, whenTNT ran the movie all day, I left the TV on.

reviews.review_title: Don't miss the followup movie "It Runs In The Family".
reviews.content: A Christmas Story was probably one of my least favorite Christmas movies for years, and I have a dozen or so favorites that I watch nightly as we approach every Christmas. But by relenting some years to watch it after all my favorites had been seen, I have to admit that it has grown on me to the point that this past post-Thanksgiving season I actually ordered myself a DVD copy for my holiday movie collection. Now I will look forward to watching it each year. *** What totally surprised me however was that there was a follow-up to this movie about Ralphie and the Parkers but which takes place the next summer titled: It Runs In The Family (also titled early on as My Summer Story). Being made 11 years later (1994) all the actors are different but for one heartwarming tie to A Christmas Story; the adult Ralphie narrator (also again writer/producer) remains Jean Shepherd. That plus a homage to the original early in the movie draw you right in. If you liked the original then I'd guess you will want to see this followup, with all its antics, frustrations, and silliness. I liked Charles Grodin and Mary Steenburgen as the parents and although it was a struggle for me initially to warm up to another young actor as Ralphie, he grew on me by the end of the movie. Interesting fact is that Ralphie and his younger brother Randy are played by two of the younger Culkin brothers; Kieran and Christian. I will probably want to add a copy of this to my collection if for nothing more than the tie to the original. Grab some popcorn and watch were the Parker family take you the following summer.

Definitely a movie worth watching, then watching again. Nostalgic, funny, heart-warming, appealing to all ages and ADDICTIVE pretty much sum it up. The plot is excellent and the acting is wonderful. Not just "A Christmas Story", this movie is fun to watch any time of the year. Worth checking out!

"It's a MAJOR AWARD!" First of all, this is the best movie ever. Second of all, this is the best ornament ever: http://www.longislandpress.com/2009/12/16/christmas- ornaments-for-the-green-trendy-and-slightly-disturbed/ (scroll to bottom of page)One of my neighbors has the full size leg lamp in their window. I am beyond jealous. there is really no way to explain this movie..it's a cult classic...too many great moments to describe and with a 24 hour marathon on TBS you really have no excuse to not watch it at least once. It's so much better than watching the yule log.

This film rated about a 9 for me due to its many hilarious situations, but then, it seemed as if the writers ran out of ideas (or maybe money) and just dropped everything.  The disappointing ending dropped my rating to a 7. STILL worth seeing, though.

reviews.review_title: Fun movie but egregious error not mentioned in "goofs"
reviews.content: A fun movie especially for those who were children during the time the movie took place. Sit back, enjoy, laugh, and yes, cry a bit.Perhaps the worst "goof" in the movie not mentioned in the IMDb "goofs" section was the following. Early on in the movie Ralphie is looking into a store window at the Red Ryder BB gun he wants so much. There are several toy trains running and one of these toy trains, a Lionel, is puffing smoke! Sorry guys, toy trains puffing smoke (Lionel and American Flyer)did not make their appearance until the year 1947!!! The movie is circa 1940-possibly earlier-and there just weren't any toy trains puffing smoke during this time frame.There are other errors (goofs) regarding the toy trains but I'll let someone else have a shot at the additional toy train goofs!

reviews.review_title: The Best Family Christmas Movie Ever Made!
reviews.content: I was 21 years old when this movie came out and it still reigns as my absolute favorite Christmas film of all time, as well as ranking in my TOP 10 MOVIES EVER MADE. Although I admit that I am biased towards outstandingly created and touching comedy films, this delightful holiday gem is not only on the same humor level as myself and the rest of my family and friends, but I have no doubt that it will continue to entertain generations to come, especially in this politically correct society...this Christmas classic will never grow old! Anyone who does not adore it obviously has no funny-bone in their body nor feel any sense of family holiday spirit whatsoever and I feel genuinely sorry for you! I DOUBLE-DOG DARE YOU TO SHOOT YOUR EYE OUT!

This is NOT my favorite holiday film. It's my favorite film period. I can tune in at any point and I'm just in heaven. No other film I've ever seen does this.  I've seen it a thousand times, and it's never diminished.

I find it ignorant that others might find this movie"lame". The wonder of this film is the subtleties it uses to present the full flavor of the era. This is an excellent film to not only enjoy the story - but the many nuances as well.

reviews.review_title: Have yourself a warped little Christmas!
reviews.content: "A Christmas Story" has been a staple of my holiday viewing for years now. I've always enjoyed this film for a variety of reasons.  One of the biggest is that it provides an antidote of sorts to the saccharine overdose one can suffer from watching too many Xmas movies. Okay, so it isn't "Citizen Kane."  It seems to me, though, that those who negatively critique this film are missing the point and expecting too much. It's FUN.  It's silly. It's not intended to be a serious film.  Films shouldn't always have to be deep statements on the human condition or be accurate and convincing in every detail to be enjoyable.  And it defies imagination how someone could say that "National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation" is a great holiday film, and then so openly badmouth this flick."A Christmas Story" views the holiday through what seems to me a typical kid's-eye view.  Ralphie Parker is the kid's Everyman, positively aching for The Big Day to arrive, using every ploy, no matter how ridiculous (Grizzly bears near Pulaski's Candy Store?) to get his coveted BB gun.  I particularly enjoy Ralphie's little daydreams; the outlandishness of a nine-year-old's fantasies is well-depicted here.Though the world presented is a little bit of a caricature, much of the film's view of childhood and Christmas strikes home.  It doesn't present a sugar-coated, romanticized view of childhood, a big plus in my book.

I remember watching this movie when i was a kid and feel exactly the same way about it now. the spirit of Christmas kind of dies down in you as you age but great holiday movies like this help you build up your Christmas cheer. I only watch this movie on Christmas eve and Christmas day when the marathon is on TNT its kind of a tradition of mine. For all those who haven't seen this flick really need to check it out especially with Christmas around the corner.A true holiday classic A true American classic A true classic period one of my top 5 favs of all time."you'll shoot your eye kid!"

reviews.review_title: Over-rated and not worth the time
reviews.content:
After looking for a Christmas film to watch that we hadn't already seen, this caught our eye. Being so highly rated we thought we were in for a treat, but we were wrong.
Perhaps it's only American's that appreciate this film. Being from the UK, we did not, and found it odd and not what we'd call a classic Christmas film. What the hell was going on with the weird leg lamp?
Maybe avoid if you're not a yank.

reviews.review_title: The second best holiday movie of all time!
reviews.content: By far, except for "It's A Wonderful Life", the best holiday movie of ALL time.  It is easy for me to say since I live in a small Northwest Indiana town and remember most of the things Jean Shepherd talks about in this movie.  I can even relate to a lot of the things that "Ralphie" goes through in this movie, which is why it makes me feel the way I do about this movie. The funniest thing, it has been almost 20 years since it was made, and still holds the test of time.  I can watch it 20 times every holiday season and never get tired of it.  If you have seen it, you can probably relate.  If you have not seen the movie, all I have to say is - "What are you waiting for?!"

The 1983 movie A Christmas Story is sure to make anyone's list of favorite Christmas movies of all time. This movie is based in the 1940's, but entails the same exact feel; every child has felt during Christmas. This movie brings out the true essence of the Christmas joy. The main character is a young child by the name of Ralphie, his adult figure narrates the whole movie as a serious of memories of the Christmas he get his Red Rider BB Gun.  Through the narration we too see and experience all of Ralphie's childhood memories. Most every American child can in some way relate to the excitement and experiences Ralphie is going through on the weeks before the big day. The movie starts out with Ralphie looking through a department store window, and being in awe of the rifle that sits in the fake snow. The movie then flashbacks to the 9 year old Ralphie's attempts at getting his BB Gun.This movie doesn't only encompass the exact feel of the American Christmas but is very funny. From the Chinese carolers to the leg lamp, to the famous line `you'll shoot your eye out', this movie keeps coming at you with very subtle realistic comedic situations. Randy is the perfect picture of the little brother. Randy and Ralphie have the perfect relationship as brothers; they can hate each other at times and some times feel sympathetic towards each other. The father is a stubborn set in his way character that I just love. The mother is a loving yet not submissive wife that has so many qualities most people can see in there own mother.  Ralphie's friends are smart mouth yet very normal kids.This movie brings everything together perfectly and touches on every part of ones Christmas celebrations. With absolutely clever comedy added to every aspect of the movie. Most importantly it brings in the Christmas feel better than any other Christmas movie out there. It's a movie everyone can relate too. My father for example one year wanted a BB Gun for Christmas, and when he finally got it, the first shot he took he ends up shooting himself in the cheek. The fact that his name is Ralph makes this story even weirder. Probably your experiences aren't so closely related to the movies, but most everyone can relate to either going to the department store to visit Santa, or running down the stairs Christmas morning with a huge wide eye look. If you need to get into the holiday spirit I guarantee A Christmas Story will help get you there. When I watched it I couldn't wait to go get our tree or start opening presents Christmas morning.  This movie truly does bring the holiday spirit to a level in which we all can relate and enjoy.

Reading the good comments on this movie gets a little monotonous, but then I read the "hated it"s and was totally shocked. I can see where someone might not get this movie, but the haters are such humorless prudes! Not to mention that some seem to lack basic comprehension skills (the younger brother does not LIVE under the sink, Ralphie does NOT shoot black people in his fantasies, there is not ONE clearly audible swear word,etc,etc).I saw "It's a Wonderful Life" on a flight recently, and although there were some good touches, the sappiness and especially Jimmy Stewart's overacting really got to me. I kept wishing to see the Saturday Night Live parody version where the townspeople dump Potter out of his chair and beat him up.Then I saw "A Christmas Story" again and loved it just as much as in years past. Admittedly, I don't see it every year and think the TBS marathon is a little much. But this is the only Christmas movie I know of that has recognizably human characters with all their frailties and character flaws but makes you love them nonetheless. Plus it skewers Christmas materialism better than the money-obsessed "Wonderful Life", Santa-cult "Miracle" and goody-goody "Christmas Carol". If you want to see a really gross and unwatchable Christmas movie, try "Bad Santa" for cryin out loud! "A Christmas Story" is pretty low-budget, but that becomes part of its scrappy charm. The loving period design and spot-on performances more than make up for it. If you watch it with an open mind, you won't be disappointed. If you live in a Pollyanna Christmas bubble, you may be!

This is the greatest Christmas film ever made. My brother got me to watch it a few years ago and I've loved it ever since. Every Christmas eve we watch it. My favorite part is when Ralphie Says "Oh, fudge."That always makes me laugh. There are many funny moments in this movie. Its not the greatest movie ever made but its the best Christmas movie ever made.

Great movie to share with any age group.Younger generation can see how life was in the so called good old days and the older generation can reminisce. Setting,time period and actors relationships are perfect.You feel like a fly on the wall in their home,seeing and hearing family at it's worse and best.Dad fighting with furnace and Mom the peace marker between children and their gruff Dad.Like how she finished off the leg lamp.Thank goodness we didn't have a whinny kid like Ralphie's brother in my family.Think Ralphie looks like a young Phil Donahue !!

reviews.review_title: This movie brings back sweet and innocent childhood memories.
reviews.content: This is an extraordinary movie. This movie brings back childhood memories in many people childhood. It doesn't matter what race you are, I think many people can relate to this movie.  When I was young, like Ralphie, I craved a particular toy at Christmas that I wanted very badly.  In Ralphie's case, it is the Red Ryder Rifle.  I wanted an Easy Bake oven which could bake little cakes and cookies. Mom, on the other hand, was afraid that I would get burned or accidentally set the house on fire.  No debate of safety would change mom's mind.  When the teacher asked us to write about what we wanted for Christmas, like Ralphie, I wrote about the one thing I really wanted, and had no real chance of getting - the Easy Bake oven.  I did not get a bad grade, but she did note it.  Her exact words were, "Quite a gift.  Please be careful, those things are dangerous."  Attached was a Fire Drill pamphlet. Needless to say, the Easy Bake oven was history, never got one.  This is definitely a good movie to watch when you want to drift back in memory to the 'Good old days' when Christmas had true meaning.  The generation today have swayed very far from its meaning.  Children get gifts and toys every day, so, when Christmas come around, to many, it's just another day.  Give me the good old Christmas or the 'Ralphie' kind of Christmas any time.

An incredibly charming and hilarious Christmas movie suitable for all ages. This semi-autobiographical story by Jean Shepherd (who also does the voice-over of grown-up Ralphie) recalls an idyllic childhood in middle America in the innocent 1950's. Ralphie is a ten year old boy bent on getting a Red Ryder Daisy Air Rifle for Christmas. His mother is equally determined that BB guns are too dangerous - "You'll shoot your eye out!" But it's not about the BB gun. Loaded with off-beat humor and quirky characters, this story celebrates family life and the perils and misadventures of being a kid. No matter where you grew up, or when, you will identify and commiserate with Ralphie's travails - and those of his long-suffering parents - in this Christmas treasure. It has become as much a part of my Christmas season as Bing Crosby and decorating the tree. Add it to the must-see list!!!

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies ever.
reviews.content: This is not only one of the best christmas movies ever, it is one of the best movies ever period.  I feel bad for the people that really hate this movie, you must have had an awful childhood if you can't relate to this movie.  I wouldn't change a thing about it.  I really dislike artsy people who write movies off just because they aren't as "deep" and Twin Peaks or something.  If I taught film, I'd play students this movie.

I never get tired of this movie. I watch it over and over during Christmas time. It's a feel good comedy that never gets old. I love looking at the details of the different scenes and how they dress and talk. I seem to always catch another element every time I watch it. Some of my favorite scenes are when Flick gets his tongue stuck on the flag pole at school, Flick: Ahhhh!! Don't leave me! Come back! Schwartz: Well, what are we going to do? Ralphie: I don't know. The bell rang. Flick: Don't leave me! Come back! Come back! Ahhh. The mother reminds me of my mom too. When she dresses the little brother in his snow pants, I thought of my mother. My mom bundled us up all the way too. We walked to school and she would glop Vaseline on our faces and made us where the ugliest boots. She didn't care about fashion as long as we were warm.

For some reason, I had never seen this movie, in spite of its popularity. So this year I decided to tape it and watch it.I can't say I'm really disappointed, I just didn't fall in love with it and I don't think I'd ever watch it again. It was so stylized and exaggerated. Nothing about the characters seemed real to me (except maybe the mother).I'm 62, so I should have seen something here that related to my past. Perhaps my underlying problem is that I never wanted a BB gun -- nor any other type of gun -- and to this day don't understand the appeal. So I cannot relate from the get-go. Nor is the father in any way shape or form like mine. I was an only child with a strong mother and grandmother with whom I did all the shopping, cooking, wrapping gifts, and decorating the tree.It's a cute little movie, but it's come and gone for me.

reviews.review_title: One of the new Christmas Classics
reviews.content: My husband and I always watch this every year. We both grew up watching it and continue the tradition today with our young teenager. One year a local station had a marathon of this movie and we left it on while we decorated the tree, wrapped presents baked Christmas goodies..the movie itself seems as much of a Christmas tradition as all those things. It just seemed natural!!I look forward every year to seeing it and laugh every time!! If it is even possible that someone hasn't seen this one yet, then I highly recommend you see it now!!

I have always loved this movie. I was raised in the 1950's in Cleveland, OH, and the opening of the show is filmed in downtown Cleveland. It was near Public Square and the Terminal Tower where the trains and Rapid Transit came in. The Higbees was the one we went to often and I remember the enticing store windows at Christmas. All the department stores downtown had beautiful window displays and it made the season so magical.Everything about this show reminds me of the wonderful childhood I was fortunate to have. Such innocent times then. Everyone we knew lived in houses similar to the one shown. I also remember being bundled up in my snowsuit everyday to get to school. Didn't have "snow days" back then.When I was watching this a few years ago, my husband kept saying he wanted a leg lamp like Raphie's dad had. Ugh. Like a good wife, I secretly looked online and found a smaller version (24 inches) of it. He was thrilled. Doesn't take much to make him happy. 😄. He also remembers getting his mouth washed out with soap.Better get back to the movie. Enjoy.

reviews.review_title: Why I love and liberals will hate "A Christmas Story"
reviews.content: Why I love and liberals will hate "A Christmas Story":Unquestionably, this film contains a pro-gun message. Oh, I know the story line centers around only an air rifle. However, just as some regard marijuana as a gateway to harder drugs, in like manner, many liberals will look upon air guns as a gateway to firearms.Liberals also will view with disapproval the way in which Ralphie solved the neighborhood bully problem. When Scut Farkus saw that his beating by a much smaller boy soon would be widely known, he knew in that moment that his bullying days were over. Maybe Ralphie first should have tried to convince Farkus to attend some anger management classes.
During this time period the school were still segregated.

Seems that many of the people who hated this movie just didn't get it. Everyone's entitled to his own opinion, but most of the criticism in these reviews seems to miss the point.  This IS just a movie about a little boy who wants a bb gun for Christmas.  The scenes that people keep describing as silly or unkind are that way because the story is told just as Ralphie remembers it years later.  Sure, a department store Santa isn't likely to kick a kid down a slide.  But a kid who's desperate to get his Christmas wish (and who sees everything as an obstacle to his goal) is likely to remember it that way.  The great thing about the movie is the warm way it evokes nostalgic simplicity.  For those who complain about the lack of a plot, anything more complicated would undermine the purpose of the film.Anyway it's a great movie, and those of you who hate it should think back on your own childhood then give it another try.

As a child I read Jean Shephard's stories in Playboy and was enchanted by them. When Christmas Story came out in 1983 I rushed to the theatre and was not disappointed by this movie. I loved it.Later, my wife and I bought the VHS version and watched every Christmas. Then we watched it with our daughter. Then we bought the DVD (full frame) version and watch it every Christmas. This is a heartwarming tale of growing up in the 1930s and what Christmas means to children.Buy it and watch it!,dave

reviews.review_title: This wonderful movie is one of those rare magical moments in the history of cinema.
reviews.content: A Christmas Story spellbound me so thoroughly when I saw it in 1983 that I brought my entire family-even my brother-in-law-back to see it.  It is simply priceless, and I can see why Ted Turner and company ran it as a marathon this past Christmas.  We won't see quality and genuine warmth like this often.  With the exception of ET, I don't know when any movie has charmed and captivated its audience so well.  The entire cast and the movie setting are exceptional; Shepherd's narration, like everything else, is flawless. This is what happens when movies are honest.

I, too, count this as my favorite movie.  I'll let everyone else list the fine details of this flick.  I just saw it this past Sunday, and I have to say that my favorite part this time around was the snow!  Snow everywhere! It -looked- like Christmas.  I live in the midwest and I can't remember the last good snowy Christmas.  So, for me, the snow makes the show perfect. (Except that its the exact same patch of snow on the mail box everytime Ralphie checks it).  The Christmases of my childhood always seemed to have snow, and while I know that's not exactly true, I still miss the snow.  What I wouldn't give for a Christmas where it snows (and I live in Michigan!)

reviews.review_title: "Tonight! Tonight! It's Gonna be Mine Tonight!"
reviews.content: Those were the words that accompanied Dad Parker (Darren McGavin) as he danced a jig to celebrate the arrival of his major award.  When it comes to hilariously memorable movie lines, there aren't many films to rival this one!  It is an absolute classic, right up there with Caddyshack and Stripes.This is one of the most genuinely enjoyable family films ever produced. I've long considered McGavin to be an extremely underrated actor, and this film is a testament to his talents. Great script, great casting, great overall feel!

reviews.review_title: A Yuletide Classic That Never Grows Old!
reviews.content: Although I was only one year old when this movie came out, I enjoyed every minute of it!  I don't understand why people bash this movie, it is a great little movie (without any big-name actors).  This movie has been a tradition in my family for many, many years ever since it came out twenty years ago. I remember watching this movie on TBS and TNT every Christmas Eve and Day. I don't know why TNT runs a twenty-four hour marathon (i.e. playing it over and over twelve times on said holidays), but it is an yuletide classic that gets you in the spirit of Christmas.  Every Christmas Eve, I go to my maternal grandparents house for the annual Christmas party.  After we get through eating dinner and opening gifts, I would go into their bedroom, turn on the TV, tune it to TNT and watch it, no matter what time it is or what scene it's in!  What I am worried about is that TNT might wear out the tape it is on (they probably dub the contents of the tape onto a new one every year, I don't know!).  On Christmas Day, I open gifts, go to my paternal grandparent's for Christmas lunch (steak & baked potato), open more gifts, and watch the movie, no matter what time it is on or what scene it's in just like before!  And if that is not enough, I own the movie on tape and when it's not on TBS and/or TNT, I just stick in the tape and let it play through!  When I wear out the tape, I am getting the Special Edition DVD and play it to my heart's content (can you wear out a DVD?)!  This movie is not only a good comedy one can enjoy at Christmas, I also find it perfect at any time of the year when you need a good laugh (even if it is the middle of July)!  On a scale of one to ten, I give this film an eleven (broke the scale)!

reviews.review_title: The Best Christmas Film I Have Ever Seen!!!
reviews.content: I first saw this film when I was 6 years old (1985) and I remember sitting and watching it practically crying with laughter. It then became a Christmas tradition that every Christmas we would rent it from the video shop and watch it and even though we had seen it loads of times we all ended up crying with laughter.The famous saying from the film "You'll shoot your eye out" is a classic and for Ralphie to eventually do that is just hilarious.Anyone that sees this film will definitely want to see it again and again.
If you don't find some part of this movie that seems to have been taken directly from your childhood, you didn't have a childhood.Totally enjoyable.....

reviews.review_title: A Christmas Story- Hollywood Magic shows secrets of the heart..
reviews.content: A Christmas Story is one of Hollywood's wonderful contributions to our Christmas tradition. The genius of the story is that it pokes fun at our very egos, vanities, and material lust, (and that other kind of lust!), while keeping everything within the confines of an All-American household of young Ralphie and his baby brother, during the "peace and love" Christmas season at that.Every day in Ralphie's life is a day dominated by urgency and angst,. Even using the bathroom to use his Little Orphan Anny decoder ring becomes a frantic battle for Ralphie, because of course his baby brother needs to use the bathroom AT THAT VERY INSTANT. (Uhh.. who among us hasn't resented having their secret code-mission territoriality invaded by lesser beings using such commoner excuses??) "Jealous of a plastic lamp?" Ralphie's mom says, after smashing the lamp her husband ("the old man') has idolized as the symbol of his middle-aged virility restored by the magic of Christmas time. Notice carefully: She IS jealous of the sensuous sexuality evoked by the lamp. It is only when her husband says "Yeah, you're jealous that I won a MAJOR AWARD!" that she regains her composure, and is able to dismiss her sabotage of his "major award" as the (his) over-the-hill folly that it really is. The movie keeps jumping back and forth over this line of sexual identity, prowess, and respect afforded to us by society based on those elements. Just watch the interchange between mom and dad when Ralphie is forced to wear Aunt __'s infamous pink rabbit outfit. ("My aunt labored under the mistaken perception that I was eternally four years old, and had been born a girl.") Here it is MOM who is on the ridiculous side of the sexual identity argument ("Oh Ralphie, you look adorable in that!"), and her husband who comes to Ralphie's rescue. Ralphie knows that if any of his friends ever saw him in that outfit, it would make the rest of his schooldom an eternal hell - who among us hasn't been vulnerable to such a social disaster forced on us by forces beyond our control?) Even avoiding the doom of having to wear the insane pink rabbit outfit, Ralphie and his friends have to run the gauntlet of schoolyard bully Farkus and his toady sidekick. When (in a blitz of fighting frenzy) Ralphie turns the table and whoops Farkus, the fight is stopped by his Mom, and later Ralphie's brother hides in the cabinet under the kitchen sink, Randy terrified that "Dad's going to kill Ralphie" (for fighting). Mom placates Randy by offering a glass of music and leaving him in his under-sink cubbyhole, and that evening downplays the fight, winning Ralphie a commutation for his pending sentence (of doom, from his dad, for fighting). Ralphie says, "From that time on, my relationship with my mother changed" - no longer an emasculated little rabbit-girl, Ralphie is now her little warrior man-child. (But note: the emasculating pink-bunny outfit scene actually comes later in the movie.)That is the genius of the movie- Ralphie betrays his friends to be beaten up by Farkus, he exhibits serial cowardly deceit, denial, plotting and scheming - but HE WANTS THAT RED RYDER BB gun, and will FIGHT the forces of evil to get it: including his mom and teacher (both dressed as witches scoffing at his lack of virility in the "cheesy acting" scenes), and of course Ralphie battling "INSENSATE EVIL" in its most pure form, picking off (shooting, killing) Black Bart's insensate gang while his mom and dad cower under the kitchen table. These cheesy scenes are the Cream Topping of the movie (please forgive the mixed gastronomical metaphors!) - Ralphie may be a child, but his "Dead Eye" virility whoops the evil Black Bart's gang, secures Mom's safety, and dad is grateful, even if he has been demoted to cowering under the table.Greed, lust, "unbridled avarice", humiliation, abject terror, the terrifying drunken Santa Claus - these aren't children's themes, these are adult themes! Yet through the magic of Christmas, the magic of childhood, the MAGIC of Hollywood, we can poke fun at these human flaws, and thereby poke fun at ourselves. Chirstmas is about REDEMPTION, about a helpless infant conquering the sins and flaws of this world, and this wonderful movie captures that "TRIPLE DOG DARE" magic . Even as our lives are beset by fears, chaos, uncertainty, and insecurity, yet our innate, innocent (if scheming) childhood goodness triumphs over all. Bravo for Hollywood! Bravo for Christmas! Bravo for childhood!

My family and I can relate to every aspect of the movie, as it is a perfect carbon-copy of our Christmas's past! Now, we can recite the lines, before the characters in the movie do!

This is probably the movie that I have literally seen the most times in my life. I must have seen it over 100 times and I watch the 24 hour marathon every Christmas. I never get tired of this movie no matter how many times I see it and I don't care if I watch it in Spring or even Summer, it's still one of my all time favorite movies!

reviews.review_title: Don't watch the movie! Buy the book!
reviews.content: Ever since I saw this movie, I wanted to see it again.  It's just that kind of movie.  To prove it watch TNT on Christmas, you'll see it--I did.  I went as far as recording it.  Not to watch it over and over, but to find out who wrote it.  Just listen to the common saying: The book is always better than the movie.  It's based on In God We Trust, All Others Pay Cash and the general works of Jean Shepherd.  He wrote most of the funny chapters for Playboy Magazine, it tells you below the copyright notice.  I have yet to buy a copy to see if he still writes for them.  I just found this ironic because most of the chapters are rated PG and not XXX.  Anyway, don't buy the movie, instead, do yourself a favor and buy the book.  It's just as funny, but more clever.

a minor correction to lordsith's location comment below. the department store scene was shot in the higbee building (part of the terminal tower complex) not the halle building. also, the externals for the parade were shot just outside on public square.

OK, so after 31 years, I finally broke down and watched Christmas Story. And I have to tell you - it's two hours of my life I won't get back. There were several occasions when I was tempted to turn it off, but so many people are such fans that I thought I'd continue. Surely the good part was coming. (It wasn't.) Outside of the overtly racist Christmas caroling at the Chinese restaurant, there wasn't anything I remotely enjoyed about it. (Yes, I found fa-ra-ra-ra-ra to be funny) But at least I don't have to be the one guy that didn't see it. So there's that.

I saw this movie in the theater when it first came out. It has become a holiday tradition in our house. It has become a favorite among our children as well. A definite must see to help you get in the holiday spirit. A lot of fun.

reviews.review_title: One of the funniest movies ever made
reviews.content: Christmas just isn't Christmas without seeing this movie and laughing 'till you cry.  The characters are perfect. They captured childhood in a way that seems so familiar, it takes you back to being a child and remembering what it was like to think like a child.  It is hilarious and touching and classic.  Five Stars.

reviews.review_title: The Original BB Red Ryder Gun is at St. Catharines Ont. Museu
reviews.content: This is and has always been a great classic movie. Yesterday my Daughter, grandson and I went to the St Catharines, Ontario Museum which is on Lock 3 of the Welland Canal and take a tour through their vaults where they have the original Red Ryder BB gun, with cardboard  box, that was in the movie A Christmas Story. This was partially filmed in St. Catharines in 1983. It was really neat to be able to touch (with with gloves on) a great piece of history! We were lucky enough to have local press there and my Daughter and grandson made it into the local papers holding the gun. The museum said they only give this tour once every 5 years, so we felt very fortunate!

This is my very favorite Christmas movie of all time.  It reminds me of when I was a kid and the kinds of Christmas we used to have.
